Name: Butane, 2-methyl-
Rationale for classification: There is no concrete case report. But it was set as Category 2 from descriptions that high-concentration vapor stimulated the skin (PATTY (4th, 1994)), that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J) (1994)), and that a rash might appear on the contact site (SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSFS (1999)).

Name: 3,5-dichloro-N-(1,1-dimethyl-2-propynyl)benzamide
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of irritant effects with a Draize score of <=1, which were fully reversed within 72 hours, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1994)).

Name: chlordane , pur
Rationale for classification: It is reported that when human skin was irritated by exposed  (HSDB (2005), HSFS (2005)), a feeling of warmth, itching, and rash often appear (ATSDR (1994), HSFS (2005)). Animal data which follows standard skin irritation test is not found. But in single or repeated exposure tests, description that "a severe irritation is caused" is seen about skin symptoms (EHC 34 (1984)). Based on what mentioned above, this product is thought to have irritativeness and it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Tetrafluoroethylene
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Propane
Rationale for classification: It was carried out the outside of category from the description that only slight erythema was acknowledged transiently in the humans of ACIGH (7th, 2001), and the primary skin irritation can be disregarded.

Name: O,O-Diethyl S-(6-chloro-2,3-dihydro-2-oxobenzoxazolinyl)methyl phosphorodithioate; Phosalone
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of the human health effects (HSDB (2003)): "moderately irritating."

Name: 1,2-Bis(2-chlorophenyl)hydrazine
Rationale for classification: Although there is a description, " All Hydrazine show similar local effects depending on irritation conditions and its vapor is highly irritating to the skin", in the section for Effects on Human Health of HSDB (2004), classification is not possible because there is no data for this substance. Incidentally, [JD56] Hydrazine (CAS302-01-2) has been classified in Category 1A-1C and [ID245] Methylhydrazine (CAS60-34-4) and Phenylhydrazine (CAS100-63-0) in Category 2.

Name: Polymer of N,N'-propylenebis(dithiocarbamic acid) and zinc
Rationale for classification: The substance was "not irritating" in rabbit skin irritation tests, but no details (including exposure duration) were given (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Fujithion
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 1,2,3,6-tetrahydro-N-(trichloromethylthio)phthalimide
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that moderate to severe erythema and that accompanied by dropsy were acknowledged as a result of sticking on human skin for 24 hours (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts).

Name: p-Octylphenol
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: N,N'-(3,3'-Dichlorobiphenyl-4,4'-diyl)diammonium dichloride
Rationale for classification: Classification is not possible because there is no data. Also, for free bases (CAS 91-94-1), "no irritation" has been indicated in data from the skin irritation test with rabbits (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: (Z)-2'-methylacetophenone 4,6-dimethyl-2-pyrimidinylhydrazone
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation with a Draize score of 1.6, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1991)).

Name: N-Nitrosomorpholine
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Ethylenediamine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit temporary skin irritation tests (CICAD 15 (1999), SIDS (2003)): Exposure to ethylene diamine (for 6-12 minutes to 70% solution and for 24 hours to undiluted solution) causes dermal necrosis; the substance is considered "corrosive" to skin, though the results are not those of 4-hour application. Although classified into 1A-1C, as the 6-12 minute application of 70% solution suggests "corrosiveness," the substance is should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 5-Allyl-1,3-benzodioxole
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions, "moderately irritating" (HSDB (2005)) in the 24.hour study with rabbits and "not irritating" (HSDB (2005)) in the skin irritation test with mouse. Since the primary literature of these data is not available and details are unknown, classification is not possible. Moreover, there is a description, "Moderate" (RTECS (2007)) in the 24 hour Draize test with rabbits, although it is from an information source of List 3.

Name: m-Nitroaniline
Rationale for classification: Some human epidemiological studies provide evidence of skin irritation potential (PATTY (4th, 1999)): "The substance is rapidly absorbed through intact skin, and irritates the skin, eye and mucous membranes." However, classification is not possible since the severity of the effects is not presented.

Name: 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid
Rationale for classification: Since mild irritation was seen in the rabbit skin irritation tests with sodium salts of this product (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1985), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Methylcyclohexyl-4-chlorophenylthiophosphate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Manganese sulphate monohydrate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Disulfur dichloride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It is estimated to be "corrosive" in the skin irritation test on rabbits(IUCLID 2000), and there is also a statement that chemical burns and dermatitis are caused with exposure on humans (HSDB (2005)). Therefore, it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Diphenylamine
Rationale for classification: A report on rabbit skin irritation tests suggest that the substance is "non-irritating" (IUCLID (2000)) while epidemiological cases provide evidence of "skin, eye and mucosal irritation as major effects" (CERI Hazard Data 98-13 (1999)). These equivocal data do not allow the degree of skin irritation to be determined, and thus classification is not possible.

Name: thiosemicarbazide
Rationale for classification: Original literature is unknown although there is description which suggests the irritation on the human skin (SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSFS (2002)). On the other hand, negative skin irritation is indicated with rat in dose finding study (HSDB (2003)). But data is insufficient for carrying out a GHS classification, and it could not be classified.

Name: Manganese
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (RTECS (2004)): "mild irritation after 24 hour patch" (though the results are not those of 4 hour application).

Name: N,N-diethyl-3-(2,4,6-trimethylphenylsulfonyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-1-carboxamide
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

Name: barium peroxide
Rationale for classification: From the description that"the skin is stimulated" (ICSC, 1999; SITTIG, 4th, 2002; HSFS, 2001), it was thought that there was mild irritation and it was set as category 3.

Name: Selenious acid
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in EHC 58 (1986) of the human health effects: "Selenious acid, which is readily deliquescent, burns the skin when in contact with moisture on the skin from sweating." The substance is thus considered corrosive to the skin, though the severity of the effects is unknown. Although classified into Category 1A-1C, it should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: Ethane, 1,1,2-trichloro-1,2,2-trifluoro-
Rationale for classification: Based on description that mild irritation was admitted in the skin irritation study by the Draize method (24-hour exposure) in a rabbit (CERI Hazard Data, 1999), it was set to Category 3.

Name: Amitrol
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions "although slight erythema was observed only with higher doses, recovered in 48 hours" and "a very slight stimulativeness was found" as results of two skin irritation study on rabbits (EHC 158 (1994), ACGIH (2001)). Moreover, as for humans, mild irritations in occupational exposure and slight dermatitis on three persons among six in 24-hour apply patch tests are reported (EHC 158 (1994)). Since very slight stimulativeness was reported both on humans and animals as mentioned above, it was classified as out of Category 3.

Name: S-4-chlorobenzyl N,N-diethylthiocarbamate
Rationale for classification: Based on test data from rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2004)): "The treated animals exhibited a Draize score of 0.7, but the effects were fully reversed within 48 hours."

Name: Silver
Rationale for classification: Since it is reported to be "Slightly irritating" on rabbits (IUCLID (2000)), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: 2,3,5,6-tetrahydro-6-phenyl-imidazo[2,1-b]thiazole
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: acetamide
Rationale for classification: Based on descriptions "it has comparatively no irritativeness to the skin or mucous membrane (HSDB (2003))" and "the skin and eye are stimulated as effect of short-term exposure (ICSC (1997))", it was judged to have slight irritativeness and classified as Category 3.

Name: Triphenyl Phosphate
Rationale for classification: From description that irritation was not admitted in the test applied to the skin of the rat for 4 hours on DFGOT (2 vol. 1991) and ACGIH (7th, 2001), it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: methyl cyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl
Rationale for classification: There is description that there was no irritation in single contact to the human cutaneous (ACGIH (7th, 2001)). But it was set as Category 3 from description that slight irritation was admitted in the skin irritation test using the rabbit (NICNAS (2003)).

Name: Ethane, 1,2-dichlorotetrafluoro-
Rationale for classification: Irritation is not observed on rabbit skin as a result of spray medication with concentration of 40%. (EHC113 (1990), ACGIH (2001)). And also irritation was not observed as a test result of direct spraying on the back of the guinea pigs (EHC113 (1990)), from what stated above, it was classified as out of Category.

Name: Dihydrogen selenide
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: Thallium nitrate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on epidemiological studies of human exposure (HSDB (2006)): "The substance severely burns the skin and eye." The substance is thus considered to have corrosive effects. Although classified into Category 1A-1C, it should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: Copper monochloride
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: tetrakis(diethyldithiocarbamato-S,S')tellurium
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Hydrobromic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the report of necrosis on human skin (DFGOT vol.13 (1999)) and a statement about corrosivity (ICSC (J) (2001)).

Name: 3-(Methylsulfanyl)propanal
Rationale for classification: A result of "slight irritation" and that of "necrosis" are described in SIDS (2003) for the 4-hour skin irritation test using rabbits. Since SIDS (2003) has drawn a conclusion, "There is skin irritation," based on many experimental results including these, it was classified in Category 2.

Name: Tetrachlorodifluoroethane; CFC-112
Rationale for classification:
Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (EHC (1990)): Caused "histological changes in skin musculature" (1,1,1,2-Tetrachloro-2,2-difluoroethane).  
Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (EHC (1990)): Caused "skin erythema but no systematic or histological effects." Also based on the evidence of "mild" irritation from guinea pig skin irritation tests (24 hour application) and the evidence of human health effects: "Mildly irritating to the respiratory tract and skin" (RTECS (2006)) (1,1,2,2-Tetrachloro-1,2-difluoroethane).

Name: Diethylamine
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: There are reports of corrosivity for many studies on rabbits. (IUCLID(2000))

Name: calcium arsenate
Rationale for classification: This product was set to Category 3 from description with redness which stimulated the skin (ICSC(J),  1999; SITTIG, 4th, 2002).

Name: N-(4-tert-Butylbenzyl)-4-chloro-3-ethyl-1-methylpyrazole-5-carboxamide; Tebufenpyrad
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1993)): Non-irritating to the skin (Draize score: 0).

Name: 2-(4-chloro-6-ethylamino-1,3,5-triazin-2-yl)amino-2-methylpropiononitrile
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (24 hours, occluded) (PATTY (4th, 1999)): "Mildly irritating."

Name: Benzene, (trichloromethyl)-
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 from descriptions that irritation was observed in the application test on rabbit skin (CERI Hazard Data (2002) and SIDS (2004)) and from the report of human skin irritation (IARC 29 (1982) and CERI Hazard Data (2002)).

Name: Ethyl acrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the results of rabbit temporary skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 59 (2004)): The substance, when applied for 4 hours, causes the formation of crusts, necrotic mass and severe erythema/edema associated with cicatrices; it is considered "corrosive."

Name: Perfluoroisobutylene
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: O,O-Dimethyl S-2-[1-(N-methylcarbamoyl)ethylthio]ethyl phosphorothioate; Vamidothion
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: clopidol
Rationale for classification: Based on descriptions that the skin may be stimulated (SITTIG (47th, 2002), HSFS (2000)), it was thought that it had mild irritation and was classified as Category 3.

Name: 5-Chloro-N-{2-[4-(2-ethoxyethyl)-2,3-dimethylphenoxy]ethyl}-6-ethylpyrimidine-4-amine; Pylimidifen
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of skin irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1993)).

Name: Manganese N,N'-ethylenebis(dithiocarbamate)
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild skin irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1970)).

Name: 3,5-Dimethylphenyl N-methylcarbamate; XMC
Rationale for classification: Based on the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data): "Non-irritating."

Name: dioxacarb
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2-(4-tert-butylphenoxy)cyclohexyl 2-propynyl sulfite
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests performed according to EPA Guideline 81-4 (IUCLID (2000)): "Moderately irritating."

Name: 2-Propanol, 1-methoxy-
Rationale for classification: Since extremely slight stimulativeness was admitted in the test applied to skin of rabbits (SIDS (2001) and PATTY (1994)), it was set as Category 3.

Name: ozone
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: yttrium
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2-Phenyl-2-[(2-phenylpropan-2-yl)peroxy]propane
Rationale for classification: For patch tests in human, there have been descriptions of "slight" irritation (DFGOT vol.3 (1992)) and "slight" irritation in the patch test to 200 volunteers (Patty (5th, 2001)). Moreover, for rats, although there has been a description of "mild" irritation (Patty (5th, 2001)), and it seems to be equivalent to skin irritation Category 3 in the U.N. GHS, it was classified into "Not classified" with unemployed catergory in the country. It can be classified as Xi in the EU classification; R36/ 38 (EU-Annex I).

Name: Tetraarsenic tetrasulfide
Rationale for classification: The knowledge of this product was not acknowledged. But it was judged to have slight irritation, and it was set to category 3 from the description which indicates that an inorganic arsenic had irritation (DFGOT 21, 2005).

Name: 2,2'-[oxybis(methylene)]bisoxirane
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from descriptions that severe irritation which produced erythema, edema and eschar was acknowledged in the test using the rabbit (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), and that severe irritation and chemical burn were acknowledged when single time application was done in the rabbit skin (PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: silver nitrite
Rationale for classification: No data, although skin irritation is suspected as nitrite salt.

Name: Nonane
Rationale for classification: It was seto as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J) (1995), HSDB (2005), HSFS (2000), SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: ammonium tetrafluoroborate
Rationale for classification: There is description that the human skin is stimulated (HSFS (2000)). But it cannot be classified since the data which is supported is not found and the data is insufficient.

Name: 1-chloro-1-nitropropane
Rationale for classification: Based on the report that slight erythema is observed on rabbits (DFGOT vol.1 (1991)), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: dipotassium tetracyanoniccolate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Methyl formate
Rationale for classification: There was a report of having no irritation on rabbits (IUCLID (2000)). But based on the statement of stimulativeness on humans (PATTY (5th, 2001)), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: alpha-Cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl 2-(4-chlorophenyl)-3-methylbutyrate; Fenvalerate
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of toxic effects observed in human skin irritation studies, along with the absence of irritant effects observed in rabbit skin irritation studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1983)).

Name: 4-aminoazobenzene
Rationale for classification: There is possibility of being out of Category from statement that irritation was not observed in the rabbit skin irritation test (BUA 217 (2000)). But there is no statement in Priority 1that clearly negates hazard, it cannot be classified.

Name: Chlorine
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the descriptions that there is a case where it produced slight burn to the human face with exposure to chlorine gas (EHC 21 (1982)) and that corrosivity may be seen on skin (HSDB (2005)). In addition, there are descriptions that "frostbite and corrosivity. Skin burns and pain." as primary disaster/acute manifestation when liquid chlorine touches the skin (ICSC (J), (2000)) and that liquid chlorine causes chilblain and a burn (HSDB (2005)), contacting liquefied chlorine needs special care. This product is classified as Xi; R36/R37/R38 in EU (EU Annex I (2005)).

Name: Benzyl chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on 24-hour skin irritation tests in rabbits (SIDS (2002)): "severe flare followed by swelling and necrosis." Also based on the description of the human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 97-4 (1998)): "very strong irritation of the skin, eye and mucous membranes." The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: tellurium
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 from the descriptions that the skin is stimulated (HSFS (1999) and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: diethylmercury
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: propiolactone
Rationale for classification: From description that skin burns (blistering of the skin, hair loss, and scarring) was seen in humans evidence of exposure (HSDB (Access on May 2005)), and description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J), (1997), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)), and irritation (erythema-scarring) was accepted with mouse (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: sodium antimonate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 3,5-Dibromo-4'-nitroazobenzen-4-ol
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: cis-1,2-Dichloroethylene
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to the insufficiency of data, though human epidemiological studies provide evidence of  "irritation of the eye and skin following application of aqueous solutions" (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)).

Name: 2-[(Thiocyanatomethyl)sulfanyl]-1,3-benzothiazole
Rationale for classification: There is a description, "strong skin irritation" (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report (2008)) in the dermal stimulation study with rabbits. Furthermore, when a cited literature, U.S. EPA 73-R-05-003 (2006) was checked, there was a description, "The score 72 hours later was 7.42 and severe erythema and edema were observed." Since there is no descriptipn of irreversibility, it was classified in Category 2. Incidentally, EU division is Xi; R36/38 EU-Annex I)

Name: 2-Furaldehyde
Rationale for classification: There is description that irritation was not acknowledged by 12-hour apply on skin of rabbits (CICAD 21 (2000) and EU-RAR (2004)). But from description that irritation was acknowledged by 24-hour apply on the skin of the rabbit (EU-RAR (2004)), and from description that the skin was stimulated as affect of the humans (IARC 63 (1995), Occupational Health Recommendation of Occupational Exposure Limits (1993), and PATTY (4th, 1994)), it was set as Category 2 .

Name: phosphine
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Hydroquinone
Rationale for classification: Although there are two test examples having indicated moderate or more irritation by application with high concentration over time, other four examples show mild or less irritation. Therefore, since it is believed that the substance indicates a mild irritation, it's a good guess that it can be classified as "Category 3."

Name: Allyl alcohol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of the data on human health effects (DFGOT vol. 15 (2001)): "Corrosive and irritating to the tissues underlying the muscle, when applied to the skin," although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Hydrochloric acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: There are reports of cases that corrosivity was observed in rabbit skin irritation test with 1 - 4 hour exposure depending on concentration (SIDS (2002)), that stimulation and ulcer accompanied by skin discoloration having occurred on mice and rats with 5-30 minute exposure (SIDS (2002)), and that it also caused mild to serious stimulativeness, sore and burn (SIDS (2002)). Because of what mentioned above, this product was considered to have corrosivity, and it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Phthalic anhydride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data  2000-54 (2001)): "The substance induced moderate irritation when applied to abraded skin."

Name: Ethanamine, 2,2'-oxybis[N,N-dimethyl-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: From description that necrosis was accepted by the test applied to the rabbit skin (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was judged that there was caustic, and it was set as Category 1A-1C.

Name: piperazine dihydrochloride
Rationale for classification: From description that mild to moderate skin burn was acknowledged in the human acute evidence of exposure (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), it was judged as skin irritation and set as Category 2.

Name: Methyl methacrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (ECETOC JACC30 (1995)), with EU Risk Phrase Xi (R37/38) as a reference: Severe erythem, and moderate to severe edema with a dent in the center are observed after 24 hours of exposure; irritation caused by an application of 0.2 /kg disappears after 3 days of exposure; irritation caused by an application of 2 and 5g/kg does not disappear after 14 days of exposure.

Name: 2,4,6-Tribromophenol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4 hour application) performed in accordance with OECD Test Guideline (CICAD 66 (2005)): "The substance showed no evidence of skin irritation."

Name: Cobalt oxide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: p-Divinylbenzene
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Calcium acetylide
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1A-1C from description that it is the caustic (ICSC (J), (1995), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: ferrocene
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 from the statement of skin irritation on humans (PATTY (5th, 2001)).

Name: Chromium
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: beryllium
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Ethylene Thiourea
Rationale for classification: There is a report of one examination case. But there is no statement on such as the strength of a stimulus. So it cannot be classified because of insufficient data.

Name: Methane, bromochloro-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that burned and degeneration were admitted in the skin irritation test using the rabbit (HSDB (2005)).

Name: Cresol
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "irreversible destruction of skin tissues" (EHC 168, 1995) from the rabbit skin irritation test, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Boron
Rationale for classification:
No data available.
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID0491,CAS No.10043-35-3, Boric Acid."

Name: 2,3,5,6-Tetrachloro-p-benzoquinone
Rationale for classification: Although there are descriptions, saying, "There is possibility to stimulate the skin,"(HSDB (2002)) and " Irritation response to the skin is weak,"(BUA 85 (1993)), classification is not possible because data are insufficient. EU division is Xi; R36/38 (EU-Annex I).

Name: 2-Octanol
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement that it has slight stimulativeness on guinea pigs (PATTY (5th, 2001)), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Cellulose, nitrate
Rationale for classification: There is description which suggests a possibility of stimulating the skin (HSFS (2001)). But there is no report of a specific case, and since data is insufficient, it cannot be classified.

Name: Methyl 3-(4-methoxy-6-methyl-1,3,5-triazin-2-ylcarbamoylsulfamoyl)-2-thenoate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation reactions which cleared up by 48 hours, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1997)).

Name: antimony pentafluoride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
Skin caustic is indicated from description that "reddening/seriousness of the skin burns/Hurt, and to the skin caustic, Corrosive and Severe effect are indicated"(ICSC, 1995;HSDB, 2002;SITTIG, 4th, 2002;HSFS, 2004). But it was set as Category 1A-1C since the examination data of the animal used as the further categorizing index was not found.
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when further categorizing needs to be performed.

Name: Nitrogen monoxide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: tin difluoride
Rationale for classification: There is the description that effect was not acknowledged by the coating of the 0.1% solution (DFGOT 14, 2000) or 0.5% solution (CICAD 65, 2005) to the rabbit skin. But data is insufficient and it cannot be classified.

Name: Dinitro-2-methylphenol
Rationale for classification: No data. In addition, there is a statement that 4,6-dinitro-o-cresol stimulates the skin (ICSC (J), 2004).

Name: 2-(4-ethoxyphenyl)-2-methylpropyl 3-phenoxybenzyl ether
Rationale for classification: Based on description that it was judged to have no irritation as a result of skin primary irritation examination on rabbits (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts (1986)), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: Tris(o-cresyl) phosphate
Rationale for classification: From description that it is not the skin irritation on PATTY (4th, 1994), it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: mecarbam
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: zinc arsenate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 3-Chloro-2-methylprop-1-ene
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of corrosion (PII=7.25) (DFGOT vol.4 (1994), IUCLID82000)) in the skin irritation/corrosion test with rabbits (OECD TG 404), it was classified into Category 1. Incidentally, EU division is R34 (EU-Annex I), corresponding to Category 1.

Name: 1,4-Dioxane
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on animal skin irritation tests: "moderately irritating" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.13 (2004)) and "causes moderate, reversible irritation" (EU-RAR No.21 (2002)).

Name: dimercury dinitrate
Rationale for classification: From description with the possibility which indicates skin irritation in humans (DFGOT, vol.15, 2001[as inorganic mercury compounds]; HSFS, 1993), mild irritation was considered to be a certain thing, and it was set to Category 3.

Name: isopentyl acetate
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the evaluation of "slight irritation" in the rabbit skin irritation test (isomer mixture as test substance) (DFGOTvol.11 (1996)). In addition, there is a description that "Disappearance of the test substance of a remarkable rate can be because of volatile at the time of application" on repetitive application test of this substance on human skin. And 197 subjects did not observe irritation at all (DFGOTvol.11 (1996)).

Name: Formaldehyde
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rabbit skin irritation tests (EHC 89 (1989)): "mild to moderate" and data on human health effects (EHC 89 (1989)).

Name: 1,4,5,8-tetraaminoanthraquinone
Rationale for classification: There is no data and it cannot be classified. (It has classified into Xi; R38 in EU)

Name: 3,5-diiodo-4-octanoyloxybenzonitrile
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of slight effects with the maximum Draize score of ca. 1.0, which were fully recovered within 4 days, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2001)). The substance is thus considered non-irritating.

Name: enflurane
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the statement that the skin may be stimulated and redness and dryness may be caused (ICSC (J) (2002)) .

Name: Aniline, 4,4'-methylenebis(2-methyl)-
Rationale for classification: It was classified as "out of Category" as it does not indicate irritation in rabbit test (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Poly(oxyethylene) nonylphenyl ether
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.96 (2004)): Application of the undiluted test compound (EO2-9) produced "moderate to severe irritation" of the skin.

Name: 2,3,5,6-Tetrafluoro-4-methylbenzyl (Z)-3-(2-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoro-1-propenyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropanecarboxylate; Tefluthrin
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of only mild irritation (a mean Draize score of <=0.5), with effects resolving within 48 hours, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1992)).

Name: Ammonium chloride
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the description that as effects of short-term exposure it "stimulates the skin", and as primary disaster / an acute symptoms cause "redness" on humans (ICSC (J) (2000)).

Name: manganese borofluoride hexahydrate
Rationale for classification: There is description that the this product may stimulate the human skin (SITTIG, 2002;HSFS, 2001). But it cannot be classified since there is no supporting data and data is insufficient.

Name: Manganese dioxide
Rationale for classification: IUCLID (2000) reports epidemiological evidence of human exposure: "slightly irritating." However, classification is not possible since details are not available.

Name: 2-Methyl-1,1'-biphenyl-3-ylmethyl (Z)-3-(2-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoro-1-propenyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropanecarboxylate; Bifenthrin
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests, reported in Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1991).

Name: Ammonium fluoride
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available, though an epidemiological study provides evidence of "redness" in humans (ICSC (2004)) and thus the substance is considered to possess a potential for skin irritation.

Name: 1-Chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2000-41 (2001)): The substance produced "severe skin irritation." Although it is unknown whether the effects are reversible or not, the substance is placed in Category 2, given the fact that the results are those of 24- (not 4) hour application.

Name: octachloronaphthalene
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the statement that it may stimulate human skin and cause skin rash (HSFS (2000)).

Name: 1-methylbutyl acetate
Rationale for classification: There is a report on isomer mixture that skin irritations in short-term exposure is thought to be weak or none (ACGIH (2001), DFGOT vol.11 (1998)). Therefore, it was classified as out of Category. Skin irritation and defatting of the skin were observed in repeated exposure.

Name: bromine pentafluoride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that on contacting vapor or liquid, it hurts and causes burn and deep seated pain, and if prolonged, heat injury (ACGIH (2001)), and since it is designated to U.N. classification subsidiary risks class 8, it was classified as Category 1A-1C. Sub-categories cannot be classified.

Name: 3,3-Bis(4-hydroxyphenyl)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: N-Phenylmaleimide
Rationale for classification: Classification is not possible with inadequate data. In addition, it has been described that "Mild" (RTECS (1999)) was determined in the Draize test with rabbits although it is a source database of List3. "Mild or moderate irritation in rabbits"has been indicated in the MSDS of NIPPON SHOKUBAI (HPJ-1402-00-07 (2007)) although it is not a source of information given in List.

Name: Lead(II) acetate, trihydrate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Disulfiram
Rationale for classification: In the test applied to the skin of the rabbit of DFGOT (vol.5, 1993), slight erythema was admitted, but it disappeared 6 hours afterward. Acceptance criteria of irritation was not suited and it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: halothane
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 1,2,5-Trithiepin-3,4,6,7-tetracarbonitrile
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Methamidophos
Rationale for classification: Based on the results of rabbit skin irritation tests that suggest "no evidence of irritation" (though the results are those of 24 hour application) (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Phosphonothioic acid, phenyl-, O-(2,4-dichlorophenyl) O-ethyl ester
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Dicyclopentadiene
Rationale for classification: It was classified as "Category 2" since it was Moderate in the application test on rabbit skin (ECETOC JACC 19 (1991)).

Name: endrin
Rationale for classification: From descriptions that 24 hour exposure test on rabbits show no skin effects (EHC 130 (1992), DFGOT (vol.18, 2002), and ATSDR (1996)), it was judged that there was no skin irritation and was classified as out of Category.

Name: Perfluoro(octane-1-sulfonic acid)
Rationale for classification: There is a description, "non-irritating" in the section of Animal Toxity Studies of HSDB (2003). Moreover, there is a description, "Although K salt of this substance stimulated rabbits' eyes but not its skin," in the MOE Risk Assessment Vol 3 (2008). Moreover, when the cited literature from the MOE Risk Assessment Vol 6 (2008) referred for acute toxicity (oral), OECD: Co-operation on Existing Chemicals - Hazard Assessment of Perfluorooctane Sulfonate and its Salts.ENV/JM/RD (2002)17/FINAL.JT00135607, was checked, there was a description, "primary skin irritation scores; 0" in the skin irritation test with 6 rabbits. Because of the above-mentioned reasons it was classified into "Not classified".

Name: osmium tetraoxide
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the information that it has corrosive effects and caused serious dermatitis and blister on human cases(ACGIH (2001)) and (PATTY (5th, 2001)).

Name: Silver nitrate
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of guinea pig skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-57 (2002)):"Corrosive." Although classified into 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

Name: hexamethylphosphoric triamide
Rationale for classification: Based on description that there was severe irritation in the skin irritation test in guinea pigs (RTECS (2005)), and description that it might indicate irritation when the human skin were touched (HSFS (2001)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: Bicyclo[2.2.1]hept-5-ene-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 1,4,5,6,7,7-hexachloro-
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 from description that the moderate irritation was observed in the application test on rabbit skin in CERI Hazard Data (2002).

Name: 2,4-Dinitrotoluene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.51 (2004)): "mild irritation" (though exposure time is unknown).

Name: 1,3-diphenylguanidine
Rationale for classification: There is a description , "PII:0, no skin irritation,"(SIDS (drft,2002)) in the 24 hour skin irritation test (Draize Test) with rabbits. In addition, there is a description, "There is no skin irritation, " with regard to the effects on humans (HSDB (2005)). It was classified into "Not classified" based on the above-mentioned. EU division Xi:R38 (EU-Annex) corresponds to Category 2.

Name: 2-Isopropylphenyl N-methylcarbamate; Isoprocarb; MIPC
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)): "Non-irritating to the skin."

Name: Mercury monoxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): "reddening, irritation of the eye/skin/respiratory tract." The substance is thus considered to possess a skin irritation potential of unknown degree and could be placed in Category 2 or 3. It is classified as Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Oxalic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 1 based on the statements that burn was produced on a local skin regions with airborne dust on humans (ACGIH (2001)) that corrosivity is indicated to the skin (ICSC (J), (1996)).

Name: 2-Pentanol, 4-methyl-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 from description that the skin of the rabbit was stimulated very slightly (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: O,O-dimethyl-4-oxobenzotriazin-3-ylmethyl phosphorodithioate
Rationale for classification: Since irritation is not caused in rabbit test(ACGIH (2002), JMPR 818 (1991)), it classified as out of Category.

Name: bendiocarb
Rationale for classification: Since there is description that skin irritation is not seen in this product as a result of the animal experiments in Priority 1(PDS 52 (1982)), it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: 2,4-Dimethylaniline
Rationale for classification: It is described as "not irritating" (DFGOT Vol. 19 (1998)).for the skin irritation test comforming to OECD TG. Moreover, it is described as "skin: weak irritation" in BUA 161 (Summary, 1994). Although it seemed to correspond to UN GHS Skin irritation Category 3 based on the above-mentioned, it was classified into "Not classified", because Category 3 is not domestically adopted. In addition, there is a description, "It stimulates the skin.........causes reddening, when contacting the skin" in the section of Effects on Humans of the MOE Risk Assessment Vol 6 (2008). Moreover, there is a description "mildly irritating" in the section of EFFECTS OF SHORT-TERM EXPOSURE in the cited literature ICSC (2007).

Name: Zinc acetate, dihydrate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in EHC 221 (2001): Twenty-percent solution of zinc acetate causes mid skin irritation (slightly less irritant) ((though the results are not those of 4-hour application). The substance is considered "mildly irritating" to the skin.

Name: butyl (R)-2-[4-(4-cyano-2-fluorophenoxy)phenoxy]propionate
Rationale for classification: In rabbit skin irritation tests, mild irritation was noted immediately after the application with a score of 0.2, but the effects cleared up by 24 hours (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

Name: Divanadium pentaoxide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: tin sulphate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: trifluoroarsine
Rationale for classification: The knowledge of this product was not acknowledged. But from description that an inorganic arsenic compound indicates skin irritation (DFGOT 21, 2005), and that an arsenic compound of 3 values indicates skin corrosivity (HSDB, 2003). So it was judged that this product had mild irritation, and it was set as Category 3.

Name: Propyl acetate
Rationale for classification: As the result of open irritation test on rabbit was reported to be "mild" (RTECS (2005)), it was classified as Category 3.

Name: O-3-tert-butylphenyl N-(6-methoxy-2-pyridyl)-N-methylthiocarbamate
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1988)).

Name: zinc nitrate
Rationale for classification: From description that shows "the skin reddening/hurts and the skin is stimulated" (ICSC, 1994;HSFS, 2003), and description that "the zinc salts of strong acids indicates skin corrosivity" (PIM G020 (Poisons Information Monographs, WHO/IPCS), 1994), it was set as category 2.

Name: promecarb
Rationale for classification: There is a report that the symptoms of contact dermatitis was seen by application of this product in the past (HSDB (2003)). But there is no other information, and since data is insufficient, it cannot be classified.

Name: p-Phenylenediamine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on skin irritation tests in rabbits and guinea pigs (CERI Hazard Data 2001-31 (2002) and DFGOT vol.6 (1994)): "mild to moderate irritation" (though the results are not those of 4-hour application). Also based on the description in DFGOT vol.6 (1994) of human health effects: "mildly irritating."

Name: 3,5,5-Trimethyl-1-hexanol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4-hour application) (SIDS (2003)): "Draize scores for 24, 48, and 72 hours: Erythema = 1.83, Edema = 0.22 and PII = 2.08" and "moderate irritation."

Name: N-(2-Aminoethyl)-1,2-ethanediamine; Diethylenetriamine
Rationale for classification: Based on data on human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003), CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.50 (2004)) and the testing data of rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.50 (2004), SIDS (1996)) (administration of the undiluted solution shows "corrosiveness"), although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: binapacryl
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: zinc hexafluorosilicate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Nitrobenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (EHC 230 (2003)): "The test animals exhibited scores of '1' (only slight erythema which was barely noticed at 24 hours; the reactions resolved at 48, 72, 96 hours, i.e., scores of '0')." Also based on the description in PATTY (4th, 1999) of human effects: "The substance induced irritation of the eye and skin." The substance is thus considered a mild irritant.

Name: Blasticiden-S-benzylaminobenzenesulfonate
Rationale for classification: Data without. In addition, it is being set as Category 3 in blasticidin S (ID 1344, Chemical Abstracts Service 2079-00-7).

Name: Methylenebis(4,1-cyclohexylene) diisocyanate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "The substance produced severe skin irritation." Also based on the description in the report on guinea pig skin irritation tests: "severe erythema and edema were observed." Although the substance, as a severe skin irritant, is classified into Category 1-2 in the absence of data on reversibility, it should be placed in Category 1 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 2-(2-Naphthyloxy)propionanilide; Naproanilide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: tributyltin acetate
Rationale for classification: From the knowledge that the skin is stimulated and a burn injury is caused (HSFS, 1999), and that tributyltin compounds or organic tin compounds indicate skin irritation (DFGOT 1, 1991-atty 5th, 2001; ATSDR, 2005), it was judged that it had slight skin irritation leastways, and was set as category 3.

Name: Lead dinitrate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of acute effects on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)): "flare and pain" were observed. The substance is thus considered to produce skin irritation of unknown degree.

Name: hexachloronaphthalene
Rationale for classification: There was no concrete case report. But it was set as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J), (2001), HSFS (1999)).

Name: 2-methyl-N-[3-(1-methylethoxy)phenyl]benzamide
Rationale for classification: Based an irritation response was not observed, and based on being the Draize scores of 0 (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts (1994)), it was classified out of Category

Name: Dipotassium hexafluorosilicate
Rationale for classification: Since there was description (ICSC, 1994) that a stimulus of the human skin, reddening, and a pain, it thought that there was mild irritation and it was set as category 3.

Name: Propene, 1,3-dichloro-
Rationale for classification: Since slight erythema and dropsy was observed in rabbit skin irritation study and also seen 14 days afterward, as well as exfoliation on 4 out of 6 rabbits (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1997), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Ethylbenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of primary skin irritation tests (ATSDR (1999)): "A 24-hour application causes mild skin irritation" (ethyl benzene is considered mildly irritating to the skin, though the results are not those of 4-hour application).

Name: Narasin
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Morpholine
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: There are statements that it has the moderate irritation to human skin (ACGIH 7th, 2001, PATTY 4th, 1994), and that it may cause redness, a pain, a burn, a blister and shows caustic when attached to the skin (MOE Risk Assessment the 4th volume, 2005). On the other hand, from description that a severe necrosis, chemical burn and inflammation are acknowledged by cutaneous administration to rabbits, and it has caustic (EHC 179, 1996, PATTY 4th, 1994, International Agency for Res. on Cancer 47, 1989, ACGIH 7th, 2001), it was set as Category 1A-1C.

Name: N,N-Dimethyl-1,2,3-trithian-5-amine
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on the statement (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) that mild skin irritations was seen in the rabbit.

Name: p-benzoquinone
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that discoloration (discoloration), strong stimulativeness, and erythema were acknowledged by skin exposure as effect of the humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), PATTY (4th, 1994), and IARC 71 (1999)).

Name: Potassium bromate
Rationale for classification: Although there is a description saying, "Prolonged contacts of Bromate cause burns on the scarf skin of rabbits but they recover in a few days,"(Patty (5th, 2001)), classification is not possible because there is no information at the time of 4- hour exposure. Incidentally, there is a description, "It stimulates the skin, "in the section of the Effect of Short Term Exposure in ICSC (2006).

Name: Barium chloride, dihydrate
Rationale for classification: ICSC (2002) presents evidence of "reddening," suggesting the skin irritation potential of the substance. However, classification is not possible due to lack of study detail.

Name: Dichloropentafluoropropane; HCFC-225
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: N,N'-ethylenebis(thiocarbamoylthiozinc) bis(N,N-dimethyldithiocarbamate)
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation with a Draize score of ca.1.3, which was fully reversed within 7 days, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1986)).

Name: 1,2-Dichloroethylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" from the rabbit skin irritation test using trans-1,2-dichloroethylene (CERI Hazard Data 2000-46, 2001), although no data were available for 1,2-dichloroethylene (mixture).

Name: Tributyl(lauroyloxy)stannane
Rationale for classification:
No data available.
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID428, Tributyl Tin Chloride, CAS: 1461-22-9."

Name: o-Chloroaniline
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4 hours) performed in accordance with OECD Test Guideline 404 (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.58 (2004)): "non-irritating to the skin."

Name: dipotassium peroxide
Rationale for classification: "If touched to solid, a burned will be caused on the skin."(HSDB (2005)) From this statement, it judged that there was skin irritation and was set as Category 2.

Name: Di-n-butyl phthalate
Rationale for classification: Addendum of European Union-RAR (2004) were absent from the investigation subject of substance data. Although a description of skin irritation has been shown in CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report No.11 (2004) and EU-RAR No.29 (2003), it was modified to "Not classified" because of descriptions of the result of no irritation in the test based on OECD TG404 and no irritation as a conclusion in the addendum European Union-RAR (2004) (addendum to the Environmental section) of EU-RAR No.29 (2003).

Name: Cadmium nitrate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: o-Phenylenediamine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4 hour application) (CERI Hazard Data 99-3 (2000)): "mild irritation." Also based on the description of the human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004)): "mildly irritating to the skin." The substance is thus classified as Category 3, though the results of a dermal irritation test in rabbits (4 hours) reported in DFGOT vol.6 (1994) suggest no irritation.

Name: ditin pyrophosphate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Metribuzin
Rationale for classification: Irritation was not observed at all in rabbit skin irritation test (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts). Therefore, it was classified as out of Category. In addition, it is also reported to have no irritativeness on human skin (HSDB, 2005).

Name: tetrachloronaphthalene
Rationale for classification: There was no concrete case report. But from descriptions that the skin was stimulated slightly (ICSC (J) (2001)), and the skin might be stimulated (HSFS (2000)), it was judged that skin irritation was slight. So it was set as Category 3.

Name: O-4-Bromo-2,5-dichlorophenyl O-methyl phenylphosphorothioate
Rationale for classification: In the test of the rabbit of JMPR (WHO Pesticide Residues Series 5, 1975), since it did not indicate skin stimulative to be also drug substances and a tablet, it considered as the outside of Category.

Name: iron methanearsonate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2,4-Dinitrophenol
Rationale for classification: The substance is classified into Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety, based on the description in the report on guinea pig skin irritation tests (ATSDR (1995)): "moderately irritating," though the results of rabbit skin irritation tests suggest the substance is "mildly irritating" (CERI Hazard Data 99-9 (2000)).

Name: m-Cresol
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "irreversible destruction of skin tissues" (EHC 168 (1995)) from the rabbit skin irritation test, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 2-Vinylpyridine
Rationale for classification:
Based on the evidence of "severe irritation" from guinea pig skin irritation test (24 hour application) (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.18 (2005)).
Also based on the description in the report on human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 2000 - 40 (2001), CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.18 (2005) and PATTY (4th, 2000)): "Accidental skin contact causes burning pain, and even if the skin is immediately washed, quite severe dermatitis occurs. At the site of inflammation, reddish brown coloration subsequently develops, which takes about a month to disappear."

Name: hydroxylamine
Rationale for classification: Since there is the description which indicates skin stimulation (shot red, pain, skin timulating) in Priority 2 (ICSC (1995), SITTIG (4th, 2002)) and R37/38 is indicated of European risk phrases, it was set as category 2.

Name: fosthiazate
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) by very slight erythema only having been seen in the rabbit, it carried out the outside of Category.

Name: Beryllium sulfate, Tetrahydrate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: barium tetracyanoplatinate
Rationale for classification: There is no data of this product. But the water-soluble barium compounds are supposed to indicate skin irritation (ACGIH-TLV (2006)). Since there is description that each of barium (107 EHC (J), 1990) and cyanide (61 CICAD (J), 2004) indicate mild skin irritations, it  was set to Category 3.

Name: o-Dichlorobenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" from rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment (2005)) and human reports (SIDS (2001)).

Name: Dichloroacetylene
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: N',N'-dimethylcarbamoyl(methylthio)methylenamine N-methylcarbamate
Rationale for classification: Based on the statement (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) that irritation was not admitted by the skin irritation test using a guinea pigs, it carried out the outside of Category.

Name: Cadmium chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in HSDB (2005) of the human health effects: Short-term exposure causes smarting of the skin and first degree burns. The substance is considered "irritating" to the skin, although should be placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: disodium 3-hydroxy-4-[(2,4,5-trimethylphenyl)azo]naphthalene-2,7-disulphonate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Antimony trichloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in HSDB (2003) suggests "skin irritation," but "classification not possible" is considered appropriate, given that the data are those of Priority 2.

Name: Sulfuric acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Since pH of concentrated sulfuric acid was 1 or less, it was judged to be a corrosive substances with the GHS classification standards, and classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Benzene, 1-methoxy-2-nitro-
Rationale for classification: Since the skin irritation was not observed in rabbit examination (DFGOT vol.9 (1998)), it was classified as "out of Category."

Name: Naphthalene
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 from description that mild irritation was admitted in the test applied to the rabbit skin (DFGOT (vol.11, 1998), EU RAR (2003), EHC 202 (1998), ATSDR (2003)).

Name: fluoroacetic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
It was set as Category 1A-1C from description that there was caustic to humans (ICSC (J), (1995), SITTIG (4th, 2002)).
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when subdivision needs to be performed.

Name: carbon tetrabromide
Rationale for classification: Since it was indicated that the effect which suggested the stimulativeness of degrees from very mild to moderate was admitted as a result of the skin irritation study in a rabbit on PATTY (4th, 1994), it was judged with Category 2.

Name: Mercury diiodide
Rationale for classification: Based on the data on mercury (II) chloride (CAS: 7484-94-7), though no data are available on the present substance.

Name: Triglycidyl isocyanurate
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions that  TGIC operating workers show human skin irritation (NICNAS (1994)), and that mild moderate skin irritation on rabbits (CERI Hazard Data (2002), CICADS 8 (1998), ACGIH (7th, 2001), and NICNAS (1994)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: 2-[4-(2,4-Dichloro-m-toluoyl)-1,3-dimethyl-5-pyrazolyloxy]-4-methylacetophenone; Benzofenap
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (RTECS (2006)): "Mild" (though the results are those of 24 (not 4) hours).

Name: (E)-3-(dimethylamino)-1-methyl-3-oxoprop-1-enyl dimethyl phosphate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: diazomethane
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 as it was reported that there is stimulativeness and denudation on human skin (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Emery
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Bis(hydrogenated tallow)dimethylammonium chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests performed in accordance with OECD TG404 (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.78 (2005)): 72 hour application of the substance (the test material content: 97%) "showed no evidence of irritation."

Name: Cyclohexanone
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on the description "there is moderate stimulativeness" in CERI Hazard Data (2000).

Name: Benzothiazole
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (PATTY (4th, 2000)): "Slightly irritating."

Name: Pyridine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-70 (2002) and ACGIH (7th, 2004)): "severe damage" and "corrosion" (though no data are available on 4-hour application). The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

Name: lead dicyanide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Toxaphene
Rationale for classification: Since the result of rabbit test was Mild(ATSDR (1996)), it was classified as "Category 3."

Name: lead carbonate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2-Amino-4-[hydroxy(methyl)phosphinoyl]butyric acid; Glufosinate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of only slight irritation reactions (a mean Draize score of 0.2), which cleared up by 72 hours, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1984)).

Name: arsenic sulphides, natural
Rationale for classification: From the description that skin irritation is indicated as an arsenic compound of this product or of 3 values (HSDB, 2003;HSFS, 1998) and that description which shows that an inorganic arsenic had irritation (DFGOT 21, 2005), it was judged to have slight irritation, and it was set to category 3.

Name: O-Ethyl O-2-(isopropoxycarbonyl)phenyl N-isopropylphosphoramidothioate; Isofenphos
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4 hour application) (IUCLID (2000)): "Slightly irritating."

Name: Zirconium dichloride oxide
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on several reports which observed mild irritation in rabbit tests (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: tetrasodium 3,3'-[(3,3'-dimethyl[1,1'-biphenyl]-4,4'-diyl)bis(azo)]bis[5-amino-4-hydroxynaphthalene-2,7-disulphonate]
Rationale for classification: There is statement that skin irritations symptoms were not acknowledged by repeated administration in the test which used the rabbit (HSDB (2006)). But there is no statement which negated hazard clearly in Priority 1, it could not be classified due to shortage of data for carrying out the outside of Category.

Name: 3-Pentanone
Rationale for classification: Based on the evaluation of Mild in the examination on rabbits (ACGIH (2001)), it was classified as Category 3. .

Name: Cyclohexanol
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the statement of "only slightly irritant to the rabbit skin" (ACGIH (2001) and Patty (5th, 2001)).

Name: 5-Amino-1-[2,6-dichloro-4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]-3-cyano-4-[(trifluoromethyl)sulfinyl]pyrazole; Fipronil
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests, reported in Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995).

Name: 1-Chloro-1,1-difluoroethane; HCFC-142b
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Diantimony trioxide
Rationale for classification: "Irritative" according to EU Risk Phrase (2005), but data that can serve as evidence are unknown.

Name: Chloroethylene; Vinyl chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description on human health effects (EHC 215 (1999)) "erythema and some second-degree burns which healed without complication."

Name: Ethanol, 2-(diethylamino)-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Since corrosivityity is verified in an examination (4 hours) on rabbits under OECD guideline 404 (SIDS (2003)), it was classified as Category 1C.

Name: Methasulfocarb
Rationale for classification: Since irritation was not admitted in primary skin of rabbits irritation test (examination for agricultural-chemicals applications for registration), it carried out the outside of Category.

Name: Hydrogen peroxide
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: The conclusion with necrosis which penetrates to all layers of the skin or corrosivity is indicated in 3 minute, 1 hour, or 4 hour application on rabbits (EU-RAR (2003), ECETOC Special Report 10 (1996)), and in EU, it is classified as C; R35, therefore, this product is thought to have corrosivity on skin. However, since information is insufficient to subcategorize, it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Sulfuric acid, cadmium salt(1:1), hydrate (8/3)
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: N,N'-[1,1'-biphenyl]-4,4'-diylbisacetamide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Ethanethiol
Rationale for classification: As results of animal examinations,  "Moderate erythema (redness/inflammation)" on rabbits, "pain and skin discoloration" on rats are reported (PATTY (5th, 2001)), however, there are also descriptions that respective irritation disappeared in less than 24 hours or not sustained. Therefore, it was judged to be mild and was classified as Category 3.

Name: [(2-chlorophenyl)methylene]malononitrile
Rationale for classification: Since there was a result of Mild in skin application test on rodent (RTECS (2004)), it was classified as "Category 3."

Name: 3,3'-Dichlorobenzidine
Rationale for classification: There are a report that dermatitis with human occupational exposure (sources are limited to two reports) (the 3rd volume of MOE Risk Assessment(2004), CICAD 2 (1998), IARC 29 (1982), and ATSDR (1998)), and the potential skin sensitizers is suggested to be the cause of dermatitis (ATSDR (1998)). There is a data which suggests the possibility of primary skin irritation being low (CERI Hazard Data (2002)). But there is no animal data proving these, and data is insufficient, it cannot be classified.

Name: 1-Naphthylamine
Rationale for classification: Although a potential of stimulating the skin slightly as effect of short-term exposure to humans is suggested (HSDB (Access on Oct 2005), HSFS (2004) and ICSC (J) (2000)), there is no case reports. On the other hand, there was description that irritation was not admitted by the test which used the rabbit (IUCLID (2000), HSDB (Access on Oct 2005)). So it was set as the outside of Category.

Name: Octane
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that erythema and inflammation were observed when it contacted forearm for 1 hour and thigh for 5 hours in volunteer examination (PATTY (5th, 2001)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Acetonitrile
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report of rabbit skin irritation tests conducted in line with the EPA/OECD Guidelines (EU-RAR No.18 (2002)): Draize scores are all "0" for all subjects throughout the observation period; no skin irritation is observed.

Name: Sodium bromate
Rationale for classification: Although there is a description saying, "Prolonged contacts of Bromate cause burns on the scarf skin of rabbits but they recover in a few days,"(Patty (5th, 2001)), classification is not possible because there is no information at the time of 4- hour exposure. Incidentally, there is a description, "It stimulates the skin, "in the section of the Effect of Short Term Exposure in ICSC (2006).

Name: Hexane
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that skin irritation was seen in humans evidence of exposure (MOE Risk Assessment The 1st volume (2002), EHC 122 (1993), DFGOT vol.14 (2000), PATTY (4th, 1994), ATSDR (1999)).

Name: Calcium oxide
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Since it has corrosivity on skin (ICSC (1997)) is very irritating to damp skin (ACGIH (2001)), and is designated to UN classification class 8-III, it was classified into Category 1C.

Name: 4,4'-Methylenebis(2-methylcyclohexaneamine)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (SIDS (2005)): "Corrosive." Although classified into Category 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: O-6-Chloro-3-phenyl-4-pyridazinyl S-n-octyl thiocarbonate; Pyridate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (IUCLD (2000)): "Irritating" (though the severity of the effects is unknown).

Name: Acetaldehyde
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit skin irritation test (ACGIH (7th 2001)): "moderate irritant".

Name: Isophthalonitrile
Rationale for classification: From description that skin changes were not admitted in the test applied to the skin of the rabbit on ACGIH (7th, 2001), it was judged that there was no irritation and was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: N-(1-Ethylpropyl)-2,6-dinitro-3,4-xylidine; Pendimethalin
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: Creosote
Rationale for classification: There were differences in the result according to the creosote material coal place of produc. But there was a report of moderate stimulation about the American product (ATSDR (2002)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: triphenyltin chloride
Rationale for classification: Since the burn injury was seen in the human skin (HSDB, 2003) and the strong reaction was seen in the skin of rats (RTECS, 2004;HSDB, 2003), it was set as category 2.

Name: polybrominated biphenyl
Rationale for classification: With a single or two-week repetition application, slight erythemas and edemas were observed on rabbit or guinea pig skin (EHC 152 (1994), ATSDR (2004)), and skin reactions was not observed depending on test conditions (ATSDR (2004)), therefore, it was classified as Category 3.

Name: N-ethyl-O-methyl-O-(2-chloro-4-methylmercaptophenyl)-phosphoramido thioate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Paraffin wax
Rationale for classification: It is estimated to be mild (RTECS (2003)) and "not irritating" (IUCLID (2000)) in rabbit tests. But it was classified as out of Category because it is estimated as "not irritating" in the human skin application test (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: 1-Chloronaphthalene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in HSDB (2003) of the human health effects: "It is an irritant to the skin." Although classified into Category 2-3 in the absence of data regarding the degree of irritation, the substance should be placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Ethandioic acid, disodium salt
Rationale for classification: Data without. In addition, skin irritation may be indicated according to oxalic acid (ID No.0595, CAS No.144-62-7).

Name: thallium acetate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2-Chloro-1-(2,4-dichlorophenyl)vinylethylmethyl phosphate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: tetrasodium 3,3'-[(3,3'-dimethoxy[1,1'-biphenyl]-4,4'-diyl)bis(azo)]bis[5-amino-4-hydroxynaphthalene-2,7-disulphonate]
Rationale for classification: There is possibility of being out of Category from statement that irritation was not observed in the human skin irritation test (HSDB (2006)). But there is a statement that it caused moderate irritation or no irritation in the test on guinea pigs (HSDB (2006)), and there is no statement in Priority 1that clearly negates hazard. So it cannot be classified.

Name: ferbam
Rationale for classification: From description that dermatitis is caused to part humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT (vol.18, 2002)), it was judged that there was skin irritation and, it was set as Category 2.

Name: 4-(1,3-benzothiazol-2-yldisulfanyl)morpholine
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Tetrabromo(tetrabromophenyl)benzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on dermal studies in rabbits (EHC 152 (1994)): The technical mixtures tested "induced moderate erythematous and slight edematous response."

Name: brucine
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Methyl 2-(4,6-dimethoxy-2-pyrimidinyloxy)-6-[1-(methoxyimino)ethyl]benzoate
Rationale for classification: Based on test data from rabbit skin irritation studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)): "Caused mild irritation which persisted for up to 72 hours."

Name: Magnesium stearate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on what the possibility of skin irritations for humans was indicated (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Thiophenol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on animal skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 99-2 (2000)): "severe irritation of the skin" (though exposure duration is unknown). Also based on the description in PATTY (4th, 2000): "Dermal application of the substance induced inflammatory responses, with effects resolving by 24-48 hours." The substance is thus considered a skin irritant.

Name: Ammonium hydrogendifluoride   ((NH4)(HF2))
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
It was referred to as Category 1A-1C since it was classified with "C;R34" of European risk phrases which indicates the skin corrosivity, in addition to the description that an irritation is given to human skin and a burned is caused in Priority 2 (IUCLID (2000), SITTIG (4th, 2001)).
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when further categorizing needs to be performed.

Name: Nonylphenol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.1 (2004)): "Prolonged exposure to nonylphenol produces corrosive effects on the skin." Also based on the description in EU-RAR No.10 (2002): "Based on the results obtained in two studies, it is reasonable to consider nonylphenol to be corrosive on contact with skin." Although classified into Category 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: sodium fluoroacetate
Rationale for classification: Slight transient edema was observed in one case (HSDB (2005)). But it had concluded that there was no irritation. So it was classified as out of Category.

Name: diindium trioxide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Lead tetraoxide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Selenium hexafluoride
Rationale for classification: ICSC (J) (2002), HSDB (2003), and HSFS (2001) of Priority 2 document have description which indicates the skin irritation in humans, and it was set as Category 2.

Name: Tribromomethane; Bromoform
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Data 2000-11): "moderate irritant."

Name: 2-chloro-N-(2-cyanoethyl)acetamide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Sodium nitrite
Rationale for classification: There is possibility of skin irritation (HSFS (1999)). But it carried out the outside of category since skin irritation was not seen by the test (compliance with GLP) of the rabbit (IUCLID (1999)).

Name: Methanol
Rationale for classification: While there is description that the moderate irritation was seen after 24-hour exposure with the degreasing action in rabbit test (DFGOT vol.16 (2001)), there is description that irritation was not seen in another test which applicated it on rabbit for 20 hours obstructions, and since the test data based on exposure of less than 4 hours was not obtained, it was not able to classify.

Name: 1-(4-biphenylyloxy)-3,3-dimethyl-1-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)-2-butanol
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1984)).

Name: trifluoromethanesulphonic acid
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Carbon black
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: Cyclohexane, 5-isocyanato-1-(isocyanatomethyl)-1,3,3-trimethyl-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Since there are statements about severe irritation on humans (HSDB (2003)) and corrosivityity and severe necrosis and edematous on rabbits (IUCLID (2000), CERI Hazard Data (2000)); it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: diantimony trilead octaoxide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Iron carbonyl
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4 hour application) performed in accordance with OECD Test Guideline (IUCLID (2000)): "Not irritating."

Name: N,N-Dicyclohexan-1-yl(1,3-benzothiazol-2-ylsulfanyl)amine
Rationale for classification: Although there is a description, "moderate skin irritation" (SIDS (2004))in the 24 hour Draize test using rabbits, classification is not possible, because it is the result under a severer condition than 4 hours.

Name: Sodium Pentachlorophenate
Rationale for classification: Since there is the description with redness and the pain which stimulate human skin (ICSC(J)1997; HSDB, 2003; SITTIG, 4th, 2002), and it was classified into R36/37/38 (eyes, respiratory systems and skin are stimulated) according to EU-Annex I (Accessed in Sept.2006), it was thought that there was skin irritation and it was set as category 2.

Name: N-(tert-Butyl)-2-benzothiazolesulfenamide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests evaluated according to the Draize scheme (SIDS (2004)): "It can be concluded that the substance is essentially non irritating to the human skin, though only slight irritation was observed." Also based on the description in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.22 (2005): "There is no evidence of skin irritation."

Name: monensin
Rationale for classification: From the description that it stimulates human and rabbit skin at mild (Mild) degree (HSDB, 2002; RTECS, 2005), it was set as category 3.

Name: N-methyl-N,2,4,6-tetranitroaniline
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that there was skin irritation as effect of the humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), PATTY (4th, 1994), DFGOT (vol.1, 1998)).

Name: Diuron
Rationale for classification: Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1996) Since slight erythema was seen on the healthy skin of three among ten in the primary skin irritation test on guinea pigs, it was classified as Category 3. ACGIH (7th, 2001) and ACGIH-TLV (2005) report that there are skin irritations.

Name: Erionite
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 4-tert-Butylphenol
Rationale for classification: There is a description, "irritating (level : unknown" (SIDS (2000) in the skin irritation/corrosion test (OECD TG 404). Moreover, there are descriptions, "Moderate irritation such as erythema, edema and exfoliation" were observed but "recovered in 17 days" (SIDS (2000). On the other hand, although there are also descriptions of "corrosion" regarding draize test using rabbits, it was classified into Category 2, because SIDS (2000) has concluded "It is considered to stimulate the skin, " based on many data including these.
