In addition, there are descriptions in the same literature," PII is 0.1, 0.4 and 0.46 and skin irritation is minimal/slight, " and " PII is 2.75 and skin irritation is moderate, " in the 24 hour administration study of products containing 0.1-0.2% of this substance using rabbits. However, since these are study results with deluted liquid and there is no other data, classification is not possible due to insufficiency of data.

Name: m-Aminophenol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (RTECS (2004)): "Mild."

Name: PCB 1254; polychlorobiphenyl; Chlorodiphenyl (42% chlorine)
Rationale for classification: Since data is insufficient, it cannot be classified. Skin pathological changes, such as chloracne, were caused in the human occupational exposure (exposure to vapor). But there was no data about the stimulativeness at the time of the direct skin contact.

Name: Toluidine salts
Rationale for classification: A substance cannot be specificked (refer to the data of individual substances).

Name: tetranitromethane
Rationale for classification: Based on description that "the skin is not also stimulated in repeated exposure in humans" of DFGOTvol.4 (1992) or PATTY (4th, 1994) which are the source of Priority 1, it was considered as the outside of Category. In addition, "The skin is stimulated" is described by ICSC (J)(2004), SITTIG (47th, 2002), HSDB (2005) and HSFS (2000) which are sources of Priority 2. It was judged that all were insufficient for considering as basis of the categories since former references were not indicated.

Name: Hexanoic acid, 2-ethyl-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions, "Although undeluted liquid caused slight edema, erythema and necrosis, deluted liquid by 20% caused no or very slight edema and slight to moderate reddening" (Patty (5th, 2001)) in the study of 24 hour dermal administration to guinea pig and "slight necrosis in 5 animals and subsequent formation of slight to moderate crusts ," also in the 4 hour administration of undeluted liquid to 6 rabbits. Furthermore, there are descriptions "corrosive" in 3 cases of the 24 hour dermal stimulation study of rabbits, one of which is the result of the rabbits study in 1986 mentioned above. Although there is a description, on the other hand, "not irritating" in the dermal stimulation study (OECD TG 404, GLP) using rabbits in IUCLID (2000), delution conditions are unknown, because the primary document is a company report. Since there was a dose-dependent datum on guinea pig in the year 1955 and the existence of 3 cases in IUCLID (2000) where data were evaluated as "corrosive" without any description about recoverability could not be neglected, it was classified in Category 1.

Name: 2,4-Toluenediamine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (24-hour application) (CERI Hazard Data 2000-8 (2001)): "slightly irritating" (though the results are not those of 4-hour application).

Name: Oxirane, (butoxymethyl)-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated as effect of the humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT (vol.4, 1992), PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: 2,2'-Azobisisobutyronitrile
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rabbit skin irritation tests according to OECD Test Guideline 404 (SIDS (2002)), and negative results in human health effects (SIDS (2002)).

Name: pentaborane(9)
Rationale for classification: There was no animal examination data. But it was set as Category 2 from the description "strong stimulativeness and a burn may be caused by skin contacts" (HSFS (2000)).

Name: 1,2-Dichloroethane
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.3 (2004)): "moderate irritant."

Name: 2-bromopropane
Rationale for classification: Since change which is equivalent to basis of mild irritation in the test on rabbits indicated to ECETOC TR 66 (1992) was observed, it was classified as Category 3.

Name: tricalcium diphosphide
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the skin is stimulated (ICSC (J) (2002)).

Name: Phenol, 4-methoxy-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from descriptions that the skin of the guinea pigs was stimulated to mild or moderate (PATTY (4th, 1994)), and that it was the skin irritation without concrete case report (HSDB (2005), HSFS (2000), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: phenylphosphine
Rationale for classification: There was no concrete case report. But it was set as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (2001), HSDB (2005), and HSFS (2001)).

Name: 3-Chloropropene; Allyl chloride
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on animal skin irritation tests (SIDS (2003), CERI Hazard Data 98-26 (1999)): Mild irritation and damage to the skin are observed. And based on the data on human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 98-26 (1999)): Severe burn and pain are observed (the intensity of irritation is unknown, while the substance is corrosive to the skin), although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

Name: Tetrachloromethane
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" in rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 67, 2005).

Name: hafnium
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Pyrethrins and Pyrethroids
Rationale for classification: It was referred to as Category 3 from description that slight skin irritations were acknowledged in employment evidence of exposure on ATSDR (2003).

Name: Sodium hydroxide
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions that at 0.5% or more of concentration, it is irritating to human skin (SIDS, 2002), and causes severe corrosion (DFGOT vol.12, 1999) and that at 8% or more of concentration, it caused corrosion on pig skin (SIDS, 2002) and severe necrosis on rabbit skin with 5% and 4 hour application (ACGIH, 7th, 2001-ATTY, 5th, 2001), it was classified as Category 1A-1C. In addition, sub-categorizing is difficult.

Name: Lead oxide sulfate  (Pb4O3(SO4))
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Aluminium, triethyl-
Rationale for classification: Since skin irritation on humans was reported (HSDB (2005)) and it was classified into C;R34 (a burn is caused) in EU Annex I, it was thought to have corrosivity and was classified as Category 1.

Name: Poly(oxyethylene) octylphenyl ether
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on epidemiological studies of human exposure (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.105 (2006)): "OPE with average EO chain lengths of 1, 3, 5, 8-10, 12-13 (i.e., OPE1, OPE3, OPE5, OPE8-10, OPE12-13) caused no primary skin irritation," "OPE with EO chain lengths of 3 and longer showed no primary skin irritation." The materials are thus considered non skin irritants.

Name: Sodium 1,1'-biphenyl-2-olate
Rationale for classification: The results of rabbit skin irritation tests (24 hour application) suggest the evidence of "mild or severe irritation" (RTECS (2006)). Although classified into Category 1A-1C since the pH of 1% aqueous solution may exceed 11.5 (normally in the range of 11.2 to 11.6) (DFGOT Vol.2 (1991)), the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: bis(8-quinolinolato)copper
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2-Chlorophenol
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: For animals, "corrosion with severe skin damages such as erythema, dropsy, discoloration, etc."(ATSDR (1999)) has been described in the direct dosage study to skin of rabbits. For humans, "concern about occurrence of contact dermatitis" (HSDB (2005)) has been described. Therefore, it was classified into Category 1.

Name: Tetradecylbenzenesulphonic acid (C14)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on tetradecylbenzenesulphonic acid per se).

Name: Sodium decylbenzenesulfonate (C10)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on sodium decylbenzenesulfonate per se).

Name: Chromium zinc oxide
Rationale for classification:
Data without.
There is the description that "caustics or irritation" as influence of chromate and its salts to the skin is seen (IRIS (1998), DFGOT vol.3 (1992), DHP (13th, 2002)).

Name: tris(2,3-dibromopropyl) phosphate
Rationale for classification: Based on description without irritation by the skin irritation test using a rabbit (EHC 173, 1995;IARC 20, 1979-ATTY 4th, 1994), it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: p-Toluidine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 99-6 (2000)): "The substance induced moderate to severe irritation of the skin" (though the results are not those of 4-hour application).

Name: Shale oils
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: Hydrazine hydrate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on 4-hour rabbit skin irritation test results (NITE Initial Risk Assessment No.73 (2005)): "Dermal application of 55% aqueous solution resulted in corrosion at the site of application in seven of the 11 test animals." The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: BHC or HCH
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: Lead
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Oleum
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Since there is the description that caustic is indicated to human skin (ICSC (J), (2002)), and there is a case that this product caused a skin burn when sprayed on the worker's face (HSDB (2003)), it was set as category 1A-1C. In addition, further categorizing from this information is difficult.

Name: fensulfothion
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the statements that irritation was observed on humans with 5 consecutive days of administration (ACGIH (2001)) and that contact may indicate irritation to human skin (HSFS (2005)).

Name: petroleum ether
Rationale for classification: Failures of corneum are caused by contact for 30 minutes on the human skin. Moreover, it was set as Category 3 by publication that although pentane, hexanes, heptane, and octane which were the composition ingredient of the petroleum ether caused erythema, hyperemia, swelling, and pigmentation to human skin. But when hexanes and heptane were eliminated, the pain decreased in the short time and the discontinuation of exposure recovered unfounded (NIOSH (1997)).

Name: PCB 1254; polychlorobiphenyl; Chlorodiphenyl (42% chlorine)
Rationale for classification: Since data is insufficient, it cannot be classified. Skin pathological changes, such as chloracne, were caused in the human occupational exposure (exposure to vapor). But there was no data about the stimulativeness at the time of the direct skin contact.

Name: Dibutyltin oxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-67 (2002)): "mild irritant," though results are not those of 4-hour application. Also based on the following descriptions of human health effects: "Dibutyl tin oxide compounds generally causes skin and eye irritation," "A single application of the substance to the backs of hands of 5 human volunteers produced no skin irritation," "The workers of two plants A (n=25) and B (n=56), who have been occupationally exposed to dibutyl tin oxide, metal tin, dibutyl tin iodine and dibutyl tin dichloride throughout the manufacturing process of dibutyl tin lauric acid, have been reported to exhibit skin reactions including irritation, eruption and formation of blisters" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-67 (2002)). The substance is thus considered to produce none to slight irritation, and classified into Category 3 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: alpha-Cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl 3-(2,2-dichlorovinyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropanecarboxylate; Cypermethrin
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of local responses observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1986)).

Name: isothioate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Tetraalkyllead
Rationale for classification: A substance cannot be specified (refer to the data of individual substances).

Name: Chlorine dioxide
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated seriously (ICSC (J)(1999), HSDB (2005)).

Name: o-Divinylbenzene
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: [(Phthaloylbis(oxy)]bis(tributylstannane)
Rationale for classification:
No data available.
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID428, Tributyl Tin Chloride, CAS: 1461-22-9."

Name: Lead chromate
Rationale for classification: Cannot be classified due to the lack of data, although the substance may cause irreversible skin irritation of an unknown degree, based on the following descriptions on human health effects of hexavalent chromium and chromium compounds: "Necrosis and sloughing of the skin occurred in individuals at the site of application of a salve containing potassium chromate" (ATSDR, 2000)  and "ulceration is likely to occur among workers who have contact with high concentrations of chromic acid, sodium or potassium dichromate or chromate, or ammonium dichromate. It does not result from contact with trivalent chromium compounds" (EHC 61, 1988).

Name: 4,6-Dinitro-o-cresol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (DFGOT vol.19 (2003)): "The substance causes moderate irritation."

Name: Sodium alkyl(C16-18) sulfate
Rationale for classification: This substance has been described as causing "slight irritation" (SIDS (2007)) up to the concentration level of 31,5% in the skin irritation /corrosion test with rabbits (OECD TG 404, GLP). In addition, there is a description, "slightly irritating" (IUCLID (2000)) in the 4 hour sdministration study of this substance alone. It was classified into "Not classified" based on the above-mentioned.

Name: Phosphoric acid, 2,2-dichloroethenyl dimethyl ester, compd. with calcium bis(2,2-dichloroethenyl methyl phosphate) (2:1)
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: sulphuryl difluoride
Rationale for classification: There is no data about skin corrosivity/stimulativeness. It was set as category 2 in order to call attention, since chilblain may be started by touching the liquid when the this product is in state of a compressed liquefied gas (ICSC (J), (2001), SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Piperazine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4 hour application) (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.19 (2005), EU-RAR No.56 (2005) and DFGOT vol.9 (1998)): Severe irritation with irreversible effects, indicative of corrosivity. Although classified as Category 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: 3,4-Dinitrotoluene
Rationale for classification:
No data available.
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID413, Dinitrotoluene, CAS: 25321-14-6."

Name: Borax
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on animal skin irritation tests (PATTY (4th, 2000) and ECETOC TR63 (1995)): "mild to moderate skin irritation" (though the results are not those of 4-hour application). Also based on the description of the human health effects (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "dermatitis was observed following exposure to borax." Although classified as Category 2-3, the substance should be placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Decylbenzenesulfonic acid (C10)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on decylbenzene sulfonic acid per se).

Name: cadmium bromide
Rationale for classification: There is a statement that humans skin indicates irritation (HSDB (2005)). So data is insufficient, it cannot be classified.

Name: Diphosphorus pentasulfide
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions which suggest severe skin irritations on humans (HSFS (2001), ICSC (J), and (2004)) and moderate irritation with 24 hour exposure in rabbit skin irritation test (RTECS (2005)). Therefore, it was classified as Category 2.

Name: 2,4-dichloro-6-nitrophenol
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2,4-Di-tert-butylphenol
Rationale for classification: Since there is s description, "irritation (redness: 3.0, irritation index: 3.88/8)" (IUCLID (2000)) in the skin irritation/corrosion test with rabbits (OECD TG 404), it was classified in Category 2.

Name: Lead, tetraethyl-
Rationale for classification: It was classified as "Category 2" based on IUCLID, etc.

Name: Chromium (III) oxide
Rationale for classification:
Insufficient data available.
Most of the epidemiological studies and tests with chromium (III) gave negative results (EHC 61 (1988), ATSDR (2000), PATTY (4th, 2000)), though no data are available on the evaluation of chromium (III) oxide per se.

Name: 3-methyl-1,5-di(2,4-xylyl)-1,3,5-triazapenta-1,4-diene
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: barium hexafluorosilicate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Zinc sulphate
Rationale for classification:
No data available. 
Note: As for the classification of 7-hydrate, refer to "ID1108, CAS# 7446-70-0."

Name: Propiononitrile, 3-hydroxy-
Rationale for classification: Since the irritation of "moderate (moderately)" is indicated by the single dose (a method is unknown) to the skin of a rabbit (PATTY (5th, 2001)), and the human eyes were stimulated (ICSC (J), (2001)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: dinitrophenol
Rationale for classification: There is a statement that the human skin is stimulated (HSFS(2003)). But the data which is supported is not found. And since data is insufficient, it cannot be classified. In addition, the GHS classifications of 2,4-dinitro phenol (ID No.0419, CAS No.51-28-5) is set as category 2.

Name: Chlorpyrifos
Classification: Not classified (applicable to 72% Water dispersible granule)
Rationale for classification: Since irritation was not observed in the skin irritation test of 72% granules hidrated agent on rabbits (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: sulphur tetrafluoride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
Since there was a statement which indicated caustic to the skin in humans (ICSC (J), (2003), SITTIG (4th, 2002), HSFS (2000)), it was set as Category 1A-1C.
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when subdivision needs to be performed.

Name: Chromium trioxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 97-18 (1998)): "severe irritation" (though it is unclear whether the results are those of 4-hour application), and the human evidence of "chemical burn and necrosis over a large area of the arm" after accidental exposure (ATSDR (2000)). The substance is thus considered to cause "skin corrosion."  Although classified into 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

Name: trizinc diphosphide
Rationale for classification: Since four cases show the very slight redness 1 hour after eliminating coated gauze in the skin irritation test (3% zinc phosphites granules) using rabbits, but they were disappeared 24 hours afterward (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1992), it carried out the outside of category.

Name: Bromomethane; Methyl bromide
Rationale for classification: Based on the report of rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1979)): "One of six test animals exhibited only slight erythema after 24 hours of application. By 48 hours, the effects had resolved."

Name: Pentyl acetate
Rationale for classification: The isomer mixture was classified as Category 3 based on the observation of two rabbit skin irritation tests (the isomer mixture used as the test substance): "slight stimulativeness" and "moderate erythema, slight dropsy, and slight scaling seven days after application" (DFGOTvol.11 (1996)). In addition, there is discription that "disappearance by volatilization of the remarkable rate of a study substance could be considered at the time of application" for the examination where repetitive application of the isomer mixture on human skin. And 197 subjects did not observe irritation at all (DFGOTvol.11 (1996)).

Name: 2,2-Dibromo-2-cyanoacetamide
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions, "Administration of 0.5g caused erythema followed by exfoliation and edema" (HSDB (2008)) in the 4 hour skin irritation test with rabbits and "moderate to severe" in the cited literature (USEPA, Reregistration Eligibility Desision Document). Moreover, there is a description , "Severe" (RTECS (2008)) in the standard Draize test with rabbits. It was classified in Category 2.

Name: 4,4'-Bipyridyl
Rationale for classification: Although there is a description, "not irritating" (IUCLID (2000)) for the 24 hour skin irritation test using rats in the information source of List 2, classification is not possible, because details are unknown nor other data available.

Name: diammonium oxalate
Rationale for classification: Since ICSC (J) (1995), HSFS (1987), and HSDB (2002) had description (bubble, an ulcer, serious burned) which indicates skin irritation in the human impact, it was set as Category 2.

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on several reports which observed mild irritation in rabbit tests (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Cyanamide
Rationale for classification: Based on the test result of rabbit examination (solution with 13.33% purity), irritation was not observed(Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts (2002)), and it was classified as out of Category.

Name: Lead cyanamidate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Tris(dimethylphenyl) phosphate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.24 (2005)): "Slight erythematous responses persisted by 72 hours."

Name: 3-(3,5-Dichlorophenyl)-5-methyl-5-vinyl-1,3-oxazolidine-2,4-dione
Rationale for classification: Although there is a description of slight, momentary irritation in the 24 hour dermal stimulation study with 50% liquid using rabbits (JMPR (1995)), classification is not possible, because the liquid is not 100% and the study time is out of standards.

Name: Triethanolamine
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that skin irritation was acknowledged by high exposure levels or repeated exposure in the humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), SIDS (2005), IARC 77 (2000), NTP TR 518 (2004)).

Name: ammonium chlorate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 1-[(6-Chloro-3-pyridyl)methyl]imidazolidine-2-(N-nitro)imine
Rationale for classification: It was carried out the outside of Category based on the statement that it did not acknowledge the skin observation in any animal in rabbit test (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: Tetramethyllead
Rationale for classification:
No data available.
Refer to other data on lead and its compounds (primarily organic lead)

Name: Triethylamine
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1A-1C from description that caustic was admitted in the skin irritation test using the rabbit (ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT (vol.13, 1999)).

Name: Borane, trifluoro-
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It is reported to have corrosiveness on human skin and caused severe burns (ICSC (J), (1993), HSDB (2005)), therefore, it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: 2-Propanol, 1-(2-methoxypropoxy)- ; Dipropylene Glycol Methyl Ether
Rationale for classification: From description that irritation was not admitted in the test applied to the skin of the rabbit (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and SIDS (2001)), and from description that irritation was not admitted in the test applied to the skin of the humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT (vol.6, 1994), PATTY (4th, 1994) and SIDS (2001)), it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: O,O-dimethyl phthalimidomethyl S-phosphorodithioate
Rationale for classification: There is description which indicates irritant in Priority 2 (HSDB (2003), SITTIG (4th, 2002)). But there is no specific information, Moreover, the irritation was set to "mildly" in HSDB (2003), it was thought that irritant was slight, and it was set as 3.

Name: bis(acetato-O)dioxouranium
Rationale for classification: Since there was description that human skin is stimulated (HSDB (2002), HSFS (2000)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: Tritolyl phosphate
Rationale for classification: It was classified into "Not classified" since there has been a description that "it has been reported that although o- and p-objects moderately irritated and m-object slightly irritated the skin of guinea pig, there was no irritation to isomer mixture " in the skin irritation test with guinea pig (the 4th volume of MOE Risk Assessment (2005)). In addition, there has been a description in RTECS (2008) of "mild" with unknown exposure time in the skin irritation test with rabbits.

Name: Benzo[a]pyrene
Rationale for classification: There was no concrete case report. But it was set as Category 2 from description that the irritation accompanied by erythema and burning sensations was in the skin in the humans (HSDB (2005), HSFS (1998), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: N-tert-butyl-N'-(4-ethylbenzoyl)-3,5-dimethylbenzohydrazide
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1993)).

Name: dichloroacetic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Since "Severe (severe) "reaction was seen in Standard Draize Test to a rabbit (ACGIH(7th, 2005); RTECS (2004)), and there was description which indicates caustic to human's skin (ICSC (J) (2000)) and produces the severe stimulativeness and the severe burn (SITTIG(4th, 2002); HSFS (1999)), it was set as category 1A-1C. In addition, further categorizing from this data is difficult.

Name: Hexamethylenediamine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on several skin irritation tests with rabbits (SIDS (1996)): "Corrosive" (though the results are not those of 4-hour application). Also based on the description of the human health effects (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004)): "Corrosive to the eye, skin and respiratory tract." The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: Diammonium peroxydisulfate
Rationale for classification: For animals, the descriptions of "zero of mean score value of erythema/ edema" (SIDS (2005)) and "edema having disappeared within 24 hours (NICNAS (2001)) have been shown in a 4-hour skin irritation/corrosion test in which non-diluted solution was applied to rabbits (OECD TG 404, GLP). For humans, "irritative" has been described in either the patch test in which a 5% solution of the substance was applied, or the test in which a 17.5% solution of the substance was applied for 4 hours (SIDS (2005)). SIDS (2005) has described "slightly irritating" for rabbits and "can cause skin irritation" in a 5% or more solution of the substance for humans as a conclusion. Therefore, it was classified into Category 2. In addition, it can be classified as Xi in the EU classification; R36/ 37/ 38 (EU-Annex I), being equivalent to Category 2-3.

Name: antu
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 4-Nitrotoluene
Rationale for classification: In the test applied to the skin of the rabbit on SIDS (2005), from description that irritation was not acknowledged by zero of Draize score, it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: Potassium nitrate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the skin is stimulated (ICSC (J) (2001), HSFS (2004), SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Chromic acid   (H2Cr2O7)
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Since there is description that "irritation or caustics" is shown as the effect of chromate to the skin (IRIS (1998), DHP (13th, 2002)), and the dichromic acid potassium of the similar compound was classified into category 1(ID 262, Chemical Abstracts Service:7778-50-9), it was set as category 1A-1C. In addition, further categorizing from this data is difficult.

Name: Hexabromo-1,1'-biphenyl
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Methanesulfenyl chloride, trichloro-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that skin of guinea pig and rabbit were stimulated seriously (PATTY (4th, 1994)) .

Name: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo[b,e][1,4]dioxin
Rationale for classification: From description that hyperkeratosis and epidermal hyperplasia were accepted in the acute dermatitis exposure tests using the mouse (ATSDR (1998)), and description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J) (2003)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: o-Chlorotoluene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests performed in accordance with OECD Test Guideline 404 (SIDS (2004)): Mild irritation and erythema are observed.

Name: Propane, 1,2,3-trichloro-
Rationale for classification: It was carried out the outside of Category from description that the skin of the rabbit was not stimulated on ACGIH (7th, 2001), and description that irritation was not admitted in the test applied to the rabbit skin for 4 hours on CICAD 56 (2003).

Name: Aziridine
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It is known that this product produces a burn on human skin. Since the case where it caused refractory dermatitis has been reported (CERI Hazard Data, 2002), it was classified as Category 1. But detailed classifications cannot be performed because of insufficient data.

Name: Tributan-1-ylamine
Rationale for classification: The irritation of Amines was evaluated as Grade 1-10 in the 24 hour skin irritation test with rabbits and this substance is presumed to be stimulating, because there is a description, "Grade 4" (Patty (5th, 2001)), although it is not a datum of 4-hour exposure. Moreover, since there are descriptions, "It has skin irritation" (Patty (5th, 2001, ICSC (2005)), "burns in the skin" and "stimulating" (HSDB (2002), it was classified in Category 2, although reversibility is not unknown.

Name: Dibromochloromethane
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: 3,5-dichloroaniline
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Cumene
Rationale for classification: As for rabbits, some show moderate stimulativeness (DFGOT vol.13 (1999)). But most show mild irritation (ACGIH (2001), EU-RAR (2001), and CICAD 18 (1999)), and it was not classified as "skin irritative" in EU. So it was classified as Category 3.

Name: salinomycin
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Stannane, tributylfluoro-
Rationale for classification: From the statement that the this product indicates skin irritation which is mild (minimal) (ATSDR, 2005) and the knowledge that the tributyl tin compound or the organotin compound indicates skin irritation (DFGOT 1, 1991-atty 5th, 2001;ATSDR, 2005), it was set to category 3

Name: Ethyl 2-[4-(6-chloro-2-quinoxalinyloxy)phenoxy]propionate; Quizalofop-ethyl
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1982)).

Name: thiacloprid
Rationale for classification: It carried out the outside of Category based on the description that there is no stimulativeness in the skin irritation test using rabbits (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: Hexafluorosilicic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
Since there was description of "corroding the skin" to humans (ICSC (2004), SITTIG (4th, 2002)), and was also classified into "C;R34 (Causes burns)" of European risk phrases, it was set as category 1A-1C.
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when further categorizing needs to be performed.

Name: p-Chloroaniline
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4-hour application) performed in accordance with OECD Guidelines (CICAD 48 (2003)): Non-irritating.

Name: Copper sulfate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ICSC (J) 2001: "Severely irritates the eye and skin; inhalation of aerosols causes respiratory irritation; oral ingestion results in corrosion." The substance is thus considered to be corrosive to the skin.

Name: Disodium disulphite
Rationale for classification: Although an animal experiment shows unstimulation, there is also information that an irritation is given to humans with concentrated solution.

Name: p-Bromophenol
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: lead hydrogen arsenate
Rationale for classification: From description that produces the redness of the skin (ICSC, 1997), and the inflammation of mucosa and skin (HSDB, 2003), and that stimulates the skin (HSFS, 2001), it was judged that this product had mild irritation, and it was set to Category 3.

Name: Fenthion
Rationale for classification: Since "there was almost no irritation (Draze score 0.4)"in test on rabbits (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: cupric nitrate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: S,S,S-tributylphosphorotrithioate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: p-Xylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (EHC 190 (1997)): The substance causes skin irritation. Classified into Category 2 or 3, with the latter adopted according to the classification by EU (Category Xi).

Name: copper thiocyanate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Acetophenone
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions of slight edema (IUCLID (2000)) and mild skin reaction (RTECS (2005)) in rabbit tests, it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Di-n-octyl phthalate
Rationale for classification: The results of human patch tests suggest no evidence of skin irritation (CERI Hazard Data 2001-63 (2002)), whereas MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2005) provides some evidence of skin irritation in humans: "Dermal application of dioctyl phthalate (details of the isomer unknown) produced skin irritation and sensitization in human volunteers." These inconsistent results do not allow the presence or absence of skin irritation to be determined, and thus classification is not possible.

Name: Diiron trioxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of redness and moderate irritation on humans (ICSC (J) (2004), IUCLID (2000)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: 1-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone
Rationale for classification: Since it has been concluded not to be "skin irritation" based on the recent studies (HRC (1978) and BASF (1996) that observed almost no irritation with rats and guinea pig, it was classified into "Not classified", although severe skin irritation was observed in the previous tests with rabbit (BASF (1941,1953)) in EU-RAR (2003) and NICNAS (2000).

Name: Acetone
Rationale for classification: It was classified as out of Category from the statement of having no stimulativeness on rabbit skin (EHC 207 (1998)) and (SIDS (1999)).

Name: bis(diethyldithiocarbamato-S,S')nickel
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: O-4-cyanophenyl O,O-dimethyl phosphorothioate
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1986)).

Name: 2-Methoxyethyl acetate; Ethylene glycol monomethyl ether acetate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 1,2-Ethanediol, dinitrate
Rationale for classification: There is description which suggests the possibility of skin irritations (HSFS, 1999). But there is no other information. Therefore, it cannot be classified because of insufficient data.

Name: p-Bromo-2-fluoroacetanilide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: N-Methylaniline
Rationale for classification: Based on human epidemiological findings of "skin irritation" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-2 (2002)). Although classified into Category 2-3 because the severity of irritation is unknown, the substance should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Butadiene, hexachloro-
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: p-Cresol
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "irreversible destruction of skin tissues" (EHC 168 (1995)) from the rabbit skin irritation test, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Mercury
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible, because of a lack of data. Typical symptoms in humans include: pruritic eruption (inhalation, oral and dermal routes), skin separation associated with acrodynia (dermal exposure to mercury vapor).

Name: Demeton (mixed isomers)
Classification: Mixture:Classification not possible; O-:Classification not possible; S-:Classification not possible
Rationale for classification:
Mixture: no data.
O-body: no data.
S-body: no data.

Name: S-1-methyl-1-phenylethyl 1-piperidinecarbothioate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Stibine
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Butan-2-ol
Rationale for classification: Since it was described that there was no skin irritation in the test using the rabbit, and there was no report that indicated skin irritation in the example of human exposure (EHC 65 (1987), ACGIH (2002), DFGOT vol.19 (2003), and PATTY (4th, 1994)), it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: Dibromochloropropane
Rationale for classification: When it was applied to the normal skin in rabbit test, there was no irritation, and since even when it was applied to the brushing skin, only very slight erythema was observed. Therefore, it was classified as out of Category.

Name: butyl lactate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the moderate irritation was acknowledged by application on the skin of the rabbit (RTECS (2005)).

Name: chlorophenol
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
o-body: It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the statements that serious stimulativeness and corrosion were observed on rabbits (ATSDR (1999)) and that there were redness and pain on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)).
m-body: It was classified as Category 2 based on the statement that there are redness and pain on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)).
p-body: It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the statements that there were serious stimulativeness and corrosiveness for animals (ATSDR (1999), RTECS (2004), and IUCLID (2000)) and that there are redness and pain on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)). In addition, monochlorophenol is reported to have corrosivity on animals (ATSDR (1999)).

Name: Tetramethyltin
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: toluidine
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: cadmium cyanide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: (N-(1,1,2,2-Tetrachloroethylthio)-1,2,3,6-tetrahydrophthalimide); Captafol
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 by description that there was moderate irritation to the skin of the rabbit (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), and by description that many stimulative and allergic examples of contact dermatitis development of symptoms were reported in the agriculture and forestry pursuers of handling KYAPUTAFORU in Kumamoto, other domestic areas, and New Zealand (PIM 097 (1990), ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

Name: Alkanes, C10-13, chloro(shortchain chlorinated paraffins)
Rationale for classification: There is an information that erythema and slight edema could be seen in rabbits but such symptoms disappeared (carbon number C10-13/chloridization rate 70%) within 7 days (EU-RAR (1999)). In this datum the score value for erythema of 2 out of 3 animals is 1 (maximum: 4) and the score value for edema of 2 out of 3 animals is 1 (maximum:4 until 24 hours after application). There is an information about humans beside them that although slight erythema and dry skin were observed, the effect (carbon number C10-12/ chloridization rate 5-% 63%) was corresponding to that of the control group or there was no symptom (carbon number C12/chloridization rate 59%), and there is an information about rabbits that there is no irritation (carbon number C10-13/chloridization rate 59%) (EU-RAR (1999)). It was classified into "Not classified" based on the above-mentioned.

Name: Isobutyraldehyde
Rationale for classification: It was classified into "Not classified" since it was thought to be no irritation with PII=0.13 (ECETOC TR66 (1995)) in the skin irritation test with rabbits, and since there were two data of not irritating (IUCLID (2000)) with GLP: yes. In addition, it has been described that "moderate to severe irritation and burn in rabbits and erythema in one of six rabbits" (SIDS (2004)), "including irritation on the skin" (NTP TR472 (1999)), and "similar irritaion to other aldehydes" (Patty (5th, 2001)) were determined in the skin irritation test with rabbits. However, any data was shown in 1952 with unknown GLP and test conditions.

Name: Methomyl
Rationale for classification: Since it was judged to have no stimulativeness in the skin irritation test on rabbits (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: Fenaminosulf
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: N-Ethylaniline
Rationale for classification: Based on the description of the human health effects (ICSC (J) (2001)): "Redness and pain" (though the severity of the effects are unknown). Although the substance can be included in Category 2 or 3, it is classified as Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: iron(II) oxalate
Rationale for classification: Data without. In addition, also refer to oxalic acid (ID No.0595, CAS No.144-62-7).

Name: Disodium 4-amino-3-[4'-(2,4-diaminophenylazo)-1,1'-biphenyl-4-ylazo]-5-hydroxy-6-phenylazo-2,7-naphthalenedisulfonate; C.I. Direct Black 38
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: potassium hexafluoroantimonate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: cartap hydrochloride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: All of the result of the examination (an original object and five examinations by a tablet) of the rabbit of Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1994) were corresponsive to the outside of category. But technical products of this product is valued pH2 or less, and it was set to category 1A-1C. In addition, further categorizing is difficult.

Name: Chloroprene
Rationale for classification: Mild to moderate erythema and edemas for rabbits and the thickening of the skin with repeated administration to the mouse are reported (SIDS (2003)). And dermatitis and alopecia were seen on humans (IARC 19 (1979)). It was classified as Category 2 because there is no finding of corrosivity.

Name: Fluvalinate
Rationale for classification: Since there was description that it has "Mild (it is slight)" irritation to a rabbit and that burning sensations is given to human skin by exposures of synthetic pyrethroids compounds (all are HSDB(s) (2003)), it was set as Category 3.

Name: 2-(2-Formylhydrazino)-4-(5-nitro-2-furyl)thiazole
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on Draize skin irritation tests using rabbits (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.14 (2004)): The substance does not cause skin irritation.

Name: dibromodifluoromethane
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 3-Penten-2-one, 4-methyl-   (Mesityl oxide)
Rationale for classification: Based on descriptions that rabbits had mild or marked skin irritation (PATTY(5th, 2001) vol.6) and that redness, pains and dermatitis on humans are observed (ICSC (J) (1998), HSDB (2005)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Mevinphos
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: 2-Thioxo-3,5-dimethyltetrahydro-2H-1,3,5-thiadiazine; Dazomet
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of skin irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

Name: Phosphorus (yellow)
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: There are descriptions that it causes burn when contacting human skin (ACGIH (2001), ATSDR (1997), ICSC (2004)), and that it originates not only in thermals but in corrosive effects (ATSDR (1997)). Moreover, also in the animal studies, it is evaluated as "corrosive" or "necrosis" (IUCLID (2004), ATSDR (1997)). Based on what mentioned above, it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: 2-Ethylhexyl methacrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (CERI Hazard Data 2001-22 (2002)): "Moderate irritation."

Name: propyl nitrate
Rationale for classification: Since there is no primary skin irritation data, it cannot be classified.

Name: Molybdenum
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Trichlorotrifluoroethane; CFC-113
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests evaluated according to the Draize scheme (24 hour application) (CERI Hazard Data 98-23 (1999)): Caused "mild irritation" (1,1,2-trichloro-1,2,2-trifluoroethane).

Name: bromoacetone
Rationale for classification: It was set to category 2 from the description that stimulus on the human skin at serious degree (Severe), redness, and hurts  were seen (ICSC(J)2005; HSDB, 2003; HSFS, 2002).

Name: O,O-dimethyl O-[3-methyl-4-(methylsulfinyl)phenyl] thiophosphate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: m-bis(2,3-epoxypropoxy)benzene
Rationale for classification: It was referred to as Category 2 from description that severe irritation was acknowledged when applied to the skin of the rabbit on DFGOT (vol.7, 1996) and IARC 36 (1985).

Name: Ethane, 1,1,1-trichloro-
Rationale for classification: From descriptions that it shows irritation in human exposure cases (EHC 136 (1992), ATSDR (2004)), that moderate irritation was found on rabbits (CERI Hazard Data (1998), EHC 136 (1992), and ATSDR (2004)), and that moderate irritation was found on guinea pigs (CERI Hazard Data (1998), ACGIH (7th, 2001), and ATSDR (2004)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: potassium dicyanoaurate
Rationale for classification: There is also literature described that skin irritation is in the aqueous solutions of this product used for gold platings. But data is insufficient, it cannot be classified.

Name: potassium tetrachloroaurate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2,2'-((3,3',5,5'-tetramethyl-(1,1'-biphenyl)-4,4'-diyl)-bis(oxymethylene))-bis-oxirane
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Dichlorodinitromethane
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Ammonium undecylbenzenesulfonate (C11)
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.5 (2005)): "24 hour application of 1% aqueous solution of LAS induced moderate irritation." The substance is thus considered a moderate irritant (LAS mixtures with carbon chain lengths of 10-14; no data available on ammonium undecylbenzenesulfonate per se).

Name: 1,3,5-Triazine, hexahydro-1,3,5-trinitro-
Rationale for classification: Skin irritation is not observed on humans (Patty (4th, 1994), ATSDR (1995)). But it caused dermatitis and erythema on rabbits and the guinea pigs, respectively (ASTDR, 1995). So it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Cadmium sulphate
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: Parathion
Rationale for classification: It is based on the test result on rabbits (a mild irritant) (JMPR (1995)).

Name: 1,2-dihydro-5-nitroacenaphthylene
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: o-chlorostyrene
Rationale for classification: Based on descriptions regarding rabbit test of "irritant" (HSDB (2002)) and that "the substance is irritating to the eyes and the skin" (ICSC (2002)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Methyl cyclohexane
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 from description that the skin was stimulated without concrete case report (ICSC (J) (1997), HSDB (2005), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)), and description that mild irritating was acknowledged in the test applied to the skin of the rabbit although it was exposure for 24 hours (RTECS (2005)).

Name: 2-(Dimethylamino)ethyl acrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of skin corrosivity from the rabbit primary skin irritation tests (three reports in SIDS (2003)) and lack of data for subclassification, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 2-Propanol, 1-(2-methoxypropoxy)- ; Dipropylene Glycol Methyl Ether
Rationale for classification: From description that irritation was not admitted in the test applied to the skin of the rabbit (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and SIDS (2001)), and from description that irritation was not admitted in the test applied to the skin of the humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT (vol.6, 1994), PATTY (4th, 1994) and SIDS (2001)), it was carried out the outside of Category.

Name: Sodium dithionite
Rationale for classification: There was description that skin irritation was not admitted by the test using the rabbit (IUCLID (2000)). It was set to category 2 since there was description which suggests a potential of stimulating the human skin seriously (HSFS (2000)).

Name: Chlorosulfonic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
There is the description that there is caustic to human skin (HSDB and (2003), ICSC (J), (2001), SITTIG (4th, 2002)), and it was classified into "C;R35" in the European risk phrases. So it was set as category 1A-1C.
[view] When further categorizing needs to be performed, it is desirable to be set as category 1A from a viewpoint of safety.

Name: 1,3-dimethylbutyl acetate
Rationale for classification: Based on the statements that there is moderate irritation on rabbits (PATTY(5th, 2001) vol.6), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: Pentanal
Rationale for classification: From description that the skin of the guinea pigs was stimulated seriously (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and PATTY (4th, 1994)), and from description that the moderate irritation was admitted in the test applied to the skin of the rabbit (RTECS (2005)), it was set as Category 2 .

Name: Ferrovanadium dust
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Dimethyl 2,2,2-trichloro-1-hydroxyethylphosphonate; Trichlorfon; DEP
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of skin irritation reported in more than one skin irritation studies with rabbits (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1986, 1987)).

Name: Cyclohexene
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on the statement that redness was caused on humans (ICSC (J) (1999)).

Name: 1-Propyne
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Decanoic acid
Rationale for classification: Since there is a description, "moderately to severely irritating" (IUCLID (2000)) in the 24-hour administration study with rabbits, it was classified in Category 2.

Name: Ethyl 2-[(dimethoxyphosphinothioyl)thio]-2-phenylacetate; Phenthoate; PAP
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1978)): Non-irritating to the skin.

Name: Methane, isocyanato-
Rationale for classification: It was estimated as Moderate as a result of Draize test on rabbits, and it was reported that it also cause irritations or damages on humans (RTECS (2004)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: 2-Amino-5-nitrobenzonitrile
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: copper hexafluorosilicate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Lindane
Rationale for classification: From descriptions that irritation was not observed in the skin irritation test on rabbits (DFGOT (16 vol. 2001) and EHC 124 (1991)), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: Diethyl sulfate
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: From description that the necrosis arose by application on the skin of the rabbit (CERI Hazard Data (1996) and DFGOT (vol.20, 2003)), it was judged that there was caustic and it was set as Category 1A-1C.

Name: N-[2-[1-(4-Chlorophenyl)-1H-pyrazole-3-yloxymethyl]phenyl]-N-methoxycarbamic acid methyl ester
Rationale for classification: It was set to category 3 according to the technological direction based on the statement that the average value of the marks of erythema was 1.8 and the average value of edema were 0.4 as a result of the skin stimulus examination using rabbits (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: Selenious acid, (H2SeO3), disodium salt, pentahydrate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Pyrocatechol
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on 24-hour skin irritation tests in rabbits (ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "The substance produced mild to moderate erythema and mild edema when applied to intact skin, while necrosis when applied to abraded skin." The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

Name: Ammonium sulphamate
Rationale for classification: Animal studies show no skin irritation (ACGIH (7th, 2001), HSDB (2005)) or slight reaction with repeated administration (HSDB (2005), TOXCENTER (2005)). There are statements that there was no skin irritation (HSDB (2005), HSFS (2001)) and that skin is irritated (ACGIH (7th, 2001), HSDB (2005)) on humans. Based on the above information, skin irritativeness was thought to be weak, and it was classified as Category 3.

Name: Sodium alpha-dodecan-1-yl-omega-(sulfonatooxy)poly(oxyethylene)
Rationale for classification: Since there are descriptions, "Skin irritation and dermal dryness due to occupational contacts for a long period of time have been reported," HSDB (2002) as its toxicity effects on humans and "One with a short Ethylene oxide chain has stronger irritation against guinea pig and rabbits," regarding animals, it was classified in Category 2. In addition, there is a description, "severe" (RTECS (1997)) and "moderate" (RTECS (1999)), in the 24 hour Draize test using rabbits for the information source of List 3.

Name: Rock wool
Rationale for classification: Itching and irritation, though physical irritation, are caused (EHC 77 (1988)). It was classified as Category 3 by the statements in ACGIH (2001) and HSDB (2005).

Name: 1,2-Dichloro-4-nitrobenzene
Rationale for classification: Since the 24 hour skin irritation/corrosion test with rabbits (OECD TG 404, GLP) did not identify skin irritation (average scored values for erythema/crust and edema:0.2, 0.0) (SIDS (2003)), it was classified into "Not classified".

Name: zinc oxalate
Rationale for classification: Data without. In addition, also refer to oxalic acid (ID No.0595, CAS No.144-62-7).

Name: Bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in ATSDR (2002) and EU-RAR No.42 (2003): Phthalic acid, bis (2-ethylhecyl) causes mild irritation, if any, to the skin; Four-hour application causes mild skin irritation.

Name: Diethylphthalate
Rationale for classification: There is description that human skin is not stimulated (NTP TR429 (1995) and PATTY (4th, 1994)), and that the irritation in the examination which used the animal is slight (NTP TR429 (1995), ATSDR (1995), and PATTY (4th, 1994)). But also there is  description that irritation was admitted in 2 examples among 143 examples by the patch test for the humans (the 3rd volume of MOE Risk Assessment (2004) and CICAD 52 (2003)), and that dermatitis and eczema were admitted by adhesion on the skin (the 3rd volume of MOE Risk Assessment (2004) and Occupational Health Recommendation of Occupational Exposure Limits (1995)). So it was judged that there was skin irritation in some humans, and it was set as Category 2.

Name: Zinc chloride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: The dermal surface inflammatory change and ulcers are observed in rabbit skin irritation test (EU-RAR (2004)). Also formations of pustule and vesicles on skin in human patch test were reported (DFGOTvol.19 (2002)). Therefore it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: O-ethyl O-(4-methylthiophenyl) S-propyl dithiophosphate
Rationale for classification: It was classified as out of Category from the statement of having no stimulativeness on the examination with rabbits (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Acetic acid
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Skin necrosis and burn (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and corrosion (IUCLID (2004))were observed with application of acetic acid at 50% or more of concentration in animal experiments. Also based on EU-Annex 1:C;R35, etc. it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: S-(2-ethylsulphinyl-1-methylethyl)-O,O-dimethyl phosphorothioate
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: S-Ethyl hexahydro-1H-azepine-1-carbothioate; Molinate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of mild irritation with a Draize score of 1.83 at 24 hours, observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1985)).

Name: potassium
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: From statement with "Solid material causes severe skin burns." of HSDB (2005), it was judged as caustic (Category1A-1C).

Name: disodium tri(cyano-C)cuprate(2-)
Rationale for classification: There is no data of this product. But there is description that cyanide has weak skin irritations (CICAD(J)61(2004)), and it was set to Category 3.

Name: Toluene, 3-nitro-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 from description that the skin was stimulated slightly (ICSC (J) (2000), HSDB (2005).

Name: barium oxide, obtained by calcining witherite
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 3 from the description that there is a stimulus, redness, and a pain to the human skin (ICSC(J), 1999; HSFS, 2002), and that it stimulates the skin as water-soluble barium compounds (ACGIH-TLV, 2005).

Name: 1,1-Dimethyl-4,4-bipyridinium dichloride
Rationale for classification: In Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1991), several reports describe that the moderate stimulativeness was seen in 20% paraquat solution (several additive agents other than water are included) on rabbits skin irritation study, and redness and sloughing were seen in the pesticide formulations acute dermal toxicity tests on rats, etc. Therefore, it was thought to have relatively strong skin stimulativeness and classified as Category 2.

Name: 2-methylaziridine
Rationale for classification: Based on the description that there is severe irritation to humans and skin inflammations, bubble, and a burn may be caused (PATTY (4th, 1994), HSDB (2005), HSFS (1998), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: Hydrogen sulfide
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: N-Methyl-N-(1-naphthyl)-2-fluoroacetamide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Disodium 2,2'-vinylenebis[5-(4-morpholino-6-anilino-1,3,5-triazin-2-ylamino)benzenesulfonate]; C.I. Fluorescent 260
Rationale for classification: The results in rabbit eye irritation tests reported in IUCLD (2000) suggest that the substance is "not irritating." However, classification is not possible, with only one set of data available.

Name: Toluene
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of moderate skin irritation caused by toluene in rabbit primary skin irritation test (4 hour exposure) (EU-RAR No. 30, 2003).

Name: Methane, dimethoxy-
Rationale for classification: There was no concrete case report. But it was set as Category 2 from description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J) (1994), HSDB (2005), HSFS (2004), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Calcium chromate
Rationale for classification:
Insufficient data available
Based on the description in ACGIH (7th, 2001), ATSDR (2000), CERI Hazard Data 97-18 (1998), EHC 61 (1988) and EU-RAR No.53 (2005): Substances including calcium chromate may cause chromium ulcers and skin ulcers (chromium holes) in humans.

Name: ''mercurous oxide''
Rationale for classification: From the description with the possibility which indicates skin irritation in humans (DFGOT, vol.15, 2001 [as inorganic mercury compounds]; HSFS, 2001[irritate and burn]), it was thought that there was irritation and it was set as Category 2.

Name: Beryllium hydroxide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 2-methyl-m-phenylene diamine
Rationale for classification: Although there is no skin irritation test data of this substance, it has been described that this substance has a "skin irritation" in ICSC (2001) or that "Diaminotoluene irritates skin" in EHC 74 (1987). It may be classified as Category 2 or Category 3 since it is likely to have an irritation despite its unknown degree. It is classified into Category 2 from a viewpoint of safety. In addition, 2,5-TDA and 2,4-TDA can be classified as Category 3.

Name: Borate(1-), tetrafluoro-, hydrogen
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification:
It was set as category 1A-1C since there is the description that there is caustic to human skin and severe burns is caused (HSDB, 2003;  ICSC (J), 1995; SITTIG, 4th, 2002; HSFS, 1999), and it was set as "C;R34" by EU-Annex I (Access on Jul.2005).
[view] It is more desirable to be set as 1A from a viewpoint of safety, when further categorizing needs to be performed.

Name: 3'-Amino-4'-methoxyacetanilide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Sodium
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: From statement with "Causes severe skin burns." of HSDB (2005), it was judged as caustic (Category1A-1C).

Name: Benzophenone
Rationale for classification: There have been descriptions of "slight irritation" and "erythema, desquamation, and slight to moderate edema" in the patch tests for 24 hours employing guinea pig (Patty (5th, 2001)) and "slight irritation" in the Draize tests in which 20% solution was applied to rabbits for 24 hours (IUCLID (2000)). Moreover, it has been described that "slight to medium edema with dyskeratosis and local necrosis occurred, and medium irritation was shown with 2.0 of skin irritation index" in the test in which crack skin of rabbits was treated with 20% solution (Patty (5th, 2001)). Classification is not possible because of inadequate data.

Name: platinum
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the skin might be stimulated (HSFS (2002), SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Diacetone alcohol
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on the information of moderate irritation in irritation test on rabbits (SIDS (2000)).

Name: Diisobutyl phthalate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests performed in accordance with OECD Test Guideline 404 (IUCLID (2000)): "Not irritating."

Name: Propane, 2,2'-oxybis-
Rationale for classification: There is a description that it caused dermatitis with repetitive administration for ten days, but it was reversible (ACGIH (2001), IUCLID (2000), HSDB (2003)), and there is description that dermal reaction of rabbits in Open irritation test was "mild" (RTECS (2004)). So it was classified as Category 3.

Name: chlorophacinone
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: (1'S,6'R)-7-Chloro-2',4,6-trimethoxy-6'-methyl-3H-spiro[benzofuran-2,1'-cyclohex[2]ene]-3,4'-dione
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: 4-chloro-o-phenylenediamine
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on the statement that there is skin irritation on humans (SITTIG (47th, 2002)).

Name: 1,1-Dichloroethylene; Vinylydene dichloride
Rationale for classification: Classification is not possible due to the insufficiency of data. The substance shows positive results in rabbit skin irritation tests, which are, however, believed to be attributed to a polymerization inhibitor (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.48 (2004)). Furthermore, evidence of irritation is not reported in CICAD (2003).

Name: Aniline, N-(1-methylethyl)-
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: Cadmium chloride (CdCl2), hydrate (2:5)
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: methyl methanesulphonate
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Hydrofluoric acid
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of animal eye irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-46 (2002), EURAR No.8 (2001), ATSDR (2003) and PATTY 4th (2000)) and data on human health effects: Corrosive to the skin. The results of rabbit skin irritation tests suggest the formation of eschar (14 days after the 4-hour application of 5% aqueous solution), although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: O-2,4-dichlorophenyl O-ethyl S-propyl phosphorodithioate
Rationale for classification: Based on no evidence of irritation observed in rabbit skin irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1975)).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 3 based on several reports which observed mild irritation in rabbit tests (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Tetrachloroethylene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on human epidemiological studies and rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.65 (2005)): Severe skin irritation associated with dermal necrosis is observed, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 4,4'-(4-iminocyclohexa-2,5-dienylidenemethylene)dianiline hydrochloride
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 4'-Ethoxyacetanilide; Phenacetin
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: heptachlor
Rationale for classification: Based on description that in the rabbit skin application test both original product and 20% phthalates methyl solution show no skin irritation (PATTY (4th, 1994)), it was classified as the outside of Category.

Name: Thionyl dichloride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Corrosivity and severe irritation on animals are described (IUCLID (2000)). It was classified as Category 1A-1C based on the fact that severe skin irritations is indicated also on humans (ACGIH (2001), HSDB (2005)) and that it is classified as EU-R35.

Name: Sodium dimethyldithiocarbamate
Rationale for classification: Classification not possible due to lack of data

Name: Pentane
Rationale for classification: It is described that there is stimulativeness, such as a pain, burning sensation, and a blister, by skin application as a volunteer (test conditions, such as dosage, were unknown) (ACGIH (7th, 2001)). But from description that there was no stimulativeness to the human skin by the 24-hour patch test in the humans (EU-RAR (2003)), and that there was no stimulativeness in practice by the skin irritation study in a rabbit (the erythema and dropsy with the average values of Draize score of 0.67), it was set as the outside of Category.

Name: 2-Heptanone
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 from description that the moderate irritation was admitted in the test applied to the skin of the rabbit for 24 hours (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and PATTY (4th, 1994)).

Name: Paraformaldehyde
Rationale for classification: It was seto as Category 2 from description that severe irritation was admitted by the test using the rabbit (RTECS (2005)),  and description that the skin was stimulated (ICSC (J) (1996), HSDB (2005), HSFS (2000), and SITTIG (4th, 2002)).

Name: Furan
Rationale for classification: Although there is a description, "skin irritation"in the study with guinea pig in HSDB (2003)), this datum is not adopted, because examination of this cited literature (Gig. Saint. 6 (1974)) contained a description, "Since Furan has strong volatility (boiling point: 32degC), irritation was not examined." In addition, there is a description, "primary irritation" in the dermal administration test with rabbits in RTECS (2008), but it is an information source of List3 with details unknown. Therefore, classification is not possible, because data are insufficient. Incidentally, EU division is Xi; R38 (EU-Annex I).

Name: O-Ethyl S,S-diphenyl phosphorodithioate; Edifenphos; EDDP
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (HSDB (2006)): "Slightly irritating."

Name: Nickel
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: 1,2,3-trichlorobenzene
Rationale for classification: There is a description, "There is no irritation,"(DFGOT Vol.3 (1992)) in the 4-hour study where 500mg of this substance was administered into the skin of rabbits. On the other hand, there is a description, "moderately irritating in the skin" as an effect on human health in HSDB (2004). classification is not possible due to insufficiency of data, because there is no other datum.

Name: dimercury dichloride
Rationale for classification: From description (ICSC, 2000;CICAD, 50, 2003 ;DFGOT [as inorganic mercury compounds], vol.15, 2001 [as inorganic mercury compounds]) that the possibility indicates humans skin irritation. It thought that there was irritation and was set as Category 2.

Name: Phosphoryl trichloride
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions that it indicates corrosivity and severe irritation on animals (IUCLID (2000)) and also on humans (ACGIH (7th, 2001) and HSDB (2000), Institut national de recherche, and CDROMCD 613 (May 2000.3p.)), it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: Beryllium fluoride
Rationale for classification: Based on the human epidemiological evidence of "skin edema following exposure to dust" (ATSDR (2002), "redness and pain" (ICSC (2000)) and "irritation" (HSDB (2006)), and the description in ICSC (2000): Short-term exposure produces "severe irritation of the skin." The substance is thus considered a severe skin irritant.

Name: Silicon carbide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Ethane, 1,1,2,2-tetrachloro-
Rationale for classification: It was classified as Category 2 based on change of the skin on rabbits, congestion, dropsy, serious blister formation, and being highly and moderately irritating (CICAD 3 (1998), ATSDR (1996), IUCLID (2000)).

Name: bis(2-chloro-1-methylethyl) ether
Rationale for classification: There are no examination results of an agricultural-chemicals field object, and it cannot classify.

Name: 2-butylphenyl methylcarbamate
Rationale for classification: Since skin changes that matches criteria of mild irritation were not observed in the skin irritation test on rabbits (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: 2-Chloro-1-(2,4-dichlorophenyl)vinyl dimethyl phosphate; Dimethylvinphos
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Ethanamine
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: Based on the descriptions the necrosis of skin and burn (ACGIH (2001) and PATTY (5th, 2001)), and corrosion (IUCLID (2000)) in animal experiments, it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

Name: crotoxyphos
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: Methyl acrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of rabbit primary skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 98-10 (1999)) (necrosis is observed) and lack of data for subclassification, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: Chloroform
Rationale for classification: Based on the evidence of "slight congestion in the skin, moderate skin necrosis and incrustation" (EHC 163, 1994) from the rabbit skin irritation test, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

Name: 2-Nitrotoluene
Rationale for classification: It was carried out the outside of Category from description that irritation was not indicated in the skin of the rabbit on CERI Hazard Data (1999) and DFGOT (vol.8, 1997).

Name: Benzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit primary skin irritation tests (NICNAS (2001) and rabbit cumulative skin irritation tests (EHC 150 (1993)) as well as on EU Risk Phrase Xi; R36/38: Benzene is considered "irritating" to the skin.

Name: Fenitrothion
Rationale for classification: Since no irritant effect was seen in the test on rabbits (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts), it was classified as out of Category.

Name: Cadmium oxide
Rationale for classification: Insufficient data available

Name: N-(Cyclohexan-1-ylsulfanyl)phthalimide
Rationale for classification: Since there are descriptions, "not irritating, PII:1.7/8" (IUCLID (2000)) and "not irritating, PII:1.2/8" (IUCLID (2000)) in the Draize test with rabbits, it was classified into "Not classified".

Name: 1,3,5-Trimethylbenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-51 (2002)): "The substance induced erythema and edema; reported as skin irritant in EEC classification,"  "moderate irritation observed." Although the results are not those of 4-hour application, the substance is considered "moderately irritating" and classified into Category 2.

Name: Ether, chloromethyl methyl
Hazard statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
Rationale for classification: It was calssified as Category 1 according to the description that very strong stimulativeness which results in necrosis (CERI Hazard Data (2005)). The data which classifies sub-category A-C was not obtained.

Name: Aluminium oxide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Acenaphthene
Rationale for classification: Although "irritation" to skin and membrane has been described (Patty (5th, 2001)), the details are unknown because of a qualitative expression, data of Hazardous Materials (NFPA), and being unable to tracing the primary literature. Moreover, there have been descriptions of "not irritating" in the skin irritation test employing rabbits (IUCLID (2000)) and "irritating" in the test with unknown animal kinds (IUCLID (2000)). Therefore, classification is not possible because of no concrete data of the degree of irritation in List1.

Name: 2-Naphthol
Rationale for classification: It carried out the outside of Category from description which does not stimulate a rabbit eye (SIDS, 2006;IUCLID, 2000).

Name: 2,6-Dinitrotoluene
Rationale for classification: Based on the results of rabbit skin irritation tests that suggest no skin irritation (CERI Hazard Data 98-15(3) (1998)).

Name: Nickel sulphate
Rationale for classification: Animal studies (rat skin irritation tests using cumulative application) (EHC 108 (1991)) and human epidemiological studies (EHC 108 (1991)) provide some evidence of irritation. However, classification is not possible in the absence of data on the severity of the effects.

Name: Zinc cyanide
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Copper oxychloride
Rationale for classification: Since irritant effects, such as erythema or dropsy, were not admitted in the skin irritation test using a female rabbits (the additional data for agricultural-chemicals applications for registration, 2006), it was set to outside of category.

Name: cyanofenphos
Rationale for classification: No data available

Name: Salicylaldehyde
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-50 (2002)): "Moderate skin irritation" (though the results are not those of 4-hour application).

Name: 1,1'-Ethylene-2,2'-bipyridinium dibromide
Rationale for classification: In primary skin irritation test using rats, erythema was seen after the first application, and the applied part of skin epithelium and sloughing were seen after the second application. It recovered ten days after the third application, and new tissue was found regenerating at the applied part of the skin. Since diquat was considered to cause a mild irritation to the rat skin (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts (1985)), it was classified as Category 2.

Name: 2-Chloro-4-nitroaniline
Rationale for classification: There is a description that irritation is "slightly" shown in the 24 hour patch test with rabbits (IUCLID (2000)). Although it should be classified into "Not classified", because it was a study in many hours, classification is not possible, because it is a datum from the information source of List 2, comformance to OECD TG and GLP are unknown and there is no other data.

Name: 2-Methyl-1,3-phenylene diisocyanate
Rationale for classification: Based on the description in HSDB (2005): "Inhalation, ingestion or contact (skin, eyes) with vapors, dusts or substance may cause severe injury, burns, or death; Reaction with water or moist air will release toxic, corrosive or flammable gases; Reaction with water may generate much heat, which will increase the concentration of fumes in the air; Fire will produce irritating, corrosive and/or toxic gases; Runoff from fire control or dilution water may be corrosive and/or toxic and cause pollution," and in ICSC (J) (1998): Short-tem exposure to the substance causes "redness, burning sensation and pain," with reference to EU Risk Phrase (Category Xi: Irritating).

Name: (Z)-5,5,12,12-Tetrabutyl-7,10-dioxo-6,11-dioxa-5,12-distannahexadec-8-ene
Rationale for classification:
No data available.
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID428, Tributyl Tin Chloride, CAS: 1461-22-9."
